## PARTS EUROPE S.A.


### €175,000,000 Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes due 2022

Parts Europe S.A. (formerly Autodis S.A.), a société anonyme organized and existing under the laws of France (the “Issuer”), is offering
(the “Offering”) €175.0 million in aggregate principal amount of its Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes due 2022 (the “Senior Secured
Notes”).

The Senior Secured Notes will bear interest at a rate equal to three-month EURIBOR plus % per annum, reset quarterly. The Issuer
will pay interest on the Senior Secured Notes quarterly in arrears on each of February 1, May 1, August 1 and November 1, commencing on
May 1, 2019. The Senior Secured Notes will mature on May 1, 2022.

At any time on or after the Issue Date (as defined herein), the Issuer may redeem all or part of the Senior Secured Notes at the
redemption price set forth in this Offering Memorandum. Additionally, upon certain events defined as constituting a change of control or upon
certain asset sales, the Issuer may be required to make an offer to purchase the Senior Secured Notes. A change of control, however, will not
be deemed to have occurred if a specified consolidated net senior secured leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event. In the
event of certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuer may elect to redeem all, but not less than all, of the Senior Secured Notes.

The Senior Secured Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Issuer, ranking senior in right of payment to all of the Issuer’s future
debt that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Secured Notes and ranking pari passu in right of payment with the
Issuer’s existing and future debt that is not so subordinated, including the Issuer’s obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility (as defined
herein), the Existing Senior Secured Notes (as defined herein) and future hedging obligations (if any). The Senior Secured Notes will be
guaranteed (the “Guarantees”) on a senior secured basis by Parts Holding Europe S.A.S. (formerly Autodis Group S.A.S.), a société par
_actions simplifiée organized and existing under the laws of France, the direct parent company of the Issuer (the “Parent Guarantor”), and_
Autodistribution S.A.S., a société par actions simplifiée organized and existing under the laws of France, a direct subsidiary of the Issuer (the
“Subsidiary Guarantor” and together with the Parent Guarantor, the “Guarantors”). The Guarantees rank senior in right of payment to the
respective Guarantor’s future debt that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Guarantee and rank pari passu in right of
payment with the respective Guarantor’s existing and future debt that is not so subordinated, including such Guarantor’s obligations under the
Revolving Credit Facility and the Existing Senior Secured Notes.

The Senior Secured Notes will be secured by (i) a first-priority pledge of the share capital of Dakar Acquisition S.A., the indirect parent
company of the Issuer (“LuxCo 6”); (ii) a first-priority pledge of the capital stock, material bank accounts and material intragroup receivables
of the Parent Guarantor; (iii) a first-priority pledge of the capital stock of the Issuer (other than certain de minimis shareholdings); (iv) a
first-priority security interest over certain assets of the Issuer, including the capital stock of Autodistribution S.A.S., Magenta Auto Pièces
S.A. and SDFM S.A. held by the Issuer, its material bank accounts and its material intragroup receivables; and (v) a first-priority pledge of
(A) the capital stock of Commerce Rechange Automobiles S.A.S., Cofirhad S.A.S. and AD Grand Ouest S.A.S. held by Autodistribution
S.A.S., (B) Autodistribution S.A.S.’s material bank accounts and (C) Autodistribution S.A.S.’s material intragroup receivables (the
“Collateral”). The Revolving Credit Facility and future hedging obligations (if any) (the “Super Senior Obligations”) are secured by
first-priority security interests over, among other things, the Collateral, contractually ranking pari passu with the security interests securing
the Senior Secured Notes. Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement (as defined herein), in the event of enforcement of the security
interests over the Collateral, holders of Senior Secured Notes will receive proceeds from the Collateral only after the Super Senior Obligations
have been repaid. The validity, enforceability and, in respect of the security interests over the Collateral, priority and ranking of the
Guarantees and the security interests and the liability of the Guarantors are subject to the limitations described in “Certain insolvency law
_considerations and limitations on the validity and enforceability of the Guarantees and the security interests.” The Senior Secured Notes will_
be structurally subordinated to all obligations of the Issuer’s subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Senior Secured Notes and effectively
subordinated to any existing and future debt of the Issuer and its subsidiaries, including the Super Senior Obligations, that is secured by
property or assets that do not secure the Senior Secured Notes, to the extent of the value of such property and assets. The Revolving Credit
Facility is guaranteed by, and is secured by certain assets of, certain subsidiaries of the Issuer that do not guarantee or provide security in
favor of the Senior Secured Notes.

The Senior Secured Notes will be represented on issuance by one or more Global Notes (as defined herein), which we expect will be
delivered in book-entry form through Euroclear Bank SA/NV (“Euroclear”) and Clearstream Banking S.A. (“Clearstream”) on or
about, 2019 (the “Issue Date”). Interests in each Global Note will be exchangeable for the definitive Senior Secured Notes only in
certain limited circumstances. See “Book-entry, delivery and form.”

Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited (the “Authority”) for the listing of and permission to
deal in the Senior Secured Notes on the Official List of The International Stock Exchange (the “Exchange”). There can be no assurance that
the Senior Secured Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the Senior Secured Notes will be
granted or that such listing will be maintained.

**_IFRS 15—Revenue recognition_**

We elected to early adopt IFRS 15 as of January 1, 2017, relating to revenue recognition from contracts with
customers, using the full retrospective method, which requires restatement of each prior reporting period
presented. We applied this full retrospective method to restate our financial statements for the two years ended
December 31, 2015 and 2016. The most significant impact of the IFRS 15 standard relates to the sales of spare
parts, equipment and tools delivered directly by suppliers to independent distributors that do not transit through
our logistics platforms as they are directly delivered by suppliers to independent distributors (referred to as direct
sales transactions). Historically under IAS 18 we bear the inventory and credit risks of these products and
therefore are considered a principal in these transactions. Under IFRS 15, the guidance focuses on the transfer of
control of the products rather than the risks and, accordingly, we are considered an agent, rather than the
principal in those transactions. Therefore for the direct sales transactions, only the net amount that we retain as a
commission is recognized as revenue. This accounting better reflects our strategy to focus on transactions
involving our logistics platforms rather than direct flow transactions which do not pass through our platforms.
The IFRS 15 impacts that we have identified are mainly driven by the new principal versus agent application
guidance as explained above.

The adoption of IFRS 15 resulted in a reversal of cost of goods sold for purchase of goods from the
suppliers and a corresponding reversal of revenue previously recognized for direct sales to distributors for the
same amount. The remaining revenue represents the commission the Group earned for direct sales transactions,
including discounts received from suppliers and discounts given to the distributors. The adoption therefore had
no impact on our EBITDA or operating income in any reporting period and had no impact on the consolidated
reserves as of January 1, 2017. Adoption of the standard also did not impact the assets and liabilities on the
consolidated statement of financial position nor cash from or used in operating, financing, or investing on the
consolidated statement of cash flows. Restatements to the previously reported results due to the adoption of the
new standard on our consolidated income statements are described in note 4 to the audited consolidated financial

**Overview**

We are a leading aftermarket light vehicle spare parts distributor and truck spare parts distributor and
repairer in Western Europe, mainly active in France, Benelux and Italy, with over 55 years of experience. Since
the acquisition of Oscaro in November 2018, we have become an “omni-channel” (online and offline) distributor
in the business-to-business (“B2B”) and business-to-consumer (“do it yourself”) (“B2C (DIY)”) segments. We
hold strong regional positions in favorable markets, supported by our unique operational model and value-added
services proposition, our history of organic growth and value-accretive acquisition-led growth as well as our
strong financial profile. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2018, we generated revenue of
€1,379.2 million and an Adjusted EBITDA of €128.2 million. After giving effect to the acquisitions of Verviers
Freins and Oscaro, we had a Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA of €168.5 million for the twelve months ended
September 30, 2018.

We are the market leader in the light vehicle IAM in France, with the largest independent single-branded
distribution network and 29% market share (in terms of revenue) in 2017, and in the truck IAM in France, with
the largest independent distribution network and 18% market share (in terms of revenue) in 2017. We also hold
leading positions around the rest of Western Europe and, in 2017, we were the second largest light vehicle IAM
distributor in both Belgium and Italy and the fourth largest light vehicle IAM distributor in the Netherlands.

We have strengthened our leading position in France with the acquisition of Oscaro, the French leader in
online sales of light vehicle spare parts. Oscaro is one of the first online players to offer new spare parts from
manufacturers and wholesalers, generating the majority of its revenue from the B2C (DIY) segment. Oscaro
offers approximately 1 million SKUs and operates mainly in France and, to a lesser extent, in other markets such
as Spain. We expect the acquisition of Oscaro to help develop our international presence online, as we intend to
roll out Oscaro’s online sales platform to other countries in which we operate.

We operate our business through three operational segments which address the light vehicle independent
aftermarket in France (“Light Vehicle France”), certain light vehicle independent aftermarkets in Benelux and
Italy (“Light Vehicle International”) and the truck independent aftermarket in France (“Trucks”). The pie charts
below show the breakdown of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2017, by segment and by customer.
In the future, we will report Oscaro in a new, separate segment.

We operate in the French, Benelux and Italian independent aftermarkets. In recent years, we have grown
externally through strategic acquisitions to develop our international presence, such as with the acquisitions of
Doyen Auto in 2016, Geevers Auto Parts B.V. (“Geevers”) in May 2018 and Verviers Freins in October 2018 in
Benelux, and the acquisitions of OVAM, Ricauto and Top Car in 2017 and Genfin S.r.l. and its subsidiaries
constituting the G-Group (“G-Group”) in June 2018 in Italy. We have also grown through strategic acquisitions
to expand our complementary product offerings, such as with the acquisition of Mondial Pare-Brise in 2017,
giving us access to the windscreen and window (“auto glass”) replacement market.

We operate in the independent aftermarkets segment within the growing and resilient Western European
light vehicle spare parts distribution “core” aftermarket and the stable and mature truck spare parts distribution
and repair “core” aftermarket in France. The independent aftermarkets segment in which we operate is generally
outperforming or on par with original equipment car and truck dealer networks and the wider core aftermarkets.
The overall Western European light vehicle distribution core aftermarket is expected to grow between 1% and
3% per annum over the 2017 to 2022 period, with growth in the independent aftermarkets forecast to exceed or
be on par with this growth over the same period while gaining market share from original equipment car dealer
networks. The overall truck spare parts distribution and repair “core” aftermarket in France is forecast to grow at
a CAGR of 0.8% over the 2017 to 2022 period, with the independent aftermarkets holding stable market share
and forecast to grow at a CAGR of 0.7% over the same period. Key market drivers for both the light vehicle and
truck independent aftermarkets are expected to be favorable during the 2017 to 2022 period, including a growing
and aging addressable car parc and rising prices due to the increasing complexity of spare parts.

One of our key strengths is our control over the value chain through our proven multi-channel operational
model that delivers superior product availability and best-in-class delivery lead times. Our distribution is carried
out by a variety of wholly-owned distributors, AD-affiliated distributors and local wholesale distributors who
distribute our products to a variety of customers, including AD-branded garages, independent garages, retail
locations and online players. Our ability to control the value chain from suppliers, through logistics and
distribution, through to customers has a strong impact on margins. For example, our automated platforms enable
us to centralize more flows, which in turn generates logistics fees from suppliers. Generally, the logistics fees we
charge to suppliers are greater than the logistics costs we incur. Our unique operational model is founded on our
excellent relationships with suppliers, state-of-the-art fully-integrated logistical platforms, extensive Western
European distribution network and a broad and loyal base of customers to which we deliver a wide range of
value-added services, leading to customer loyalty. Our operational model is based on four components:
procurement and suppliers, upstream logistics control, local distribution and customers, as shown in the graphic
below.

Our model is based on the distinctive, dual proposition of distributing products to customers coupled with
providing value-added services (many of which are digital or online services) to both suppliers and customers.
To suppliers, we offer a unique access to a wide, diversified and fragmented customer base, which suppliers are
not able to efficiently address themselves. We also offer suppliers a number of value-added services, such as


2

marketing support and access to our state-of-the-art automated warehousing capabilities which allow suppliers to
arrange deliveries to a single delivery point. To customers, we provide a comprehensive product offering and
best-in-class delivery times combined with value-added services, such as commercial, technical and training
support, strong and integrated branding and online tools, which cultivate high customer loyalty and drive market
share gain.

Our revenue grew from €914 million in the year ended December 31, 2014, to €1.4 billion for the twelve
months ended September 30, 2018, with an average organic growth rate of approximately 3% per annum over the
period. For the year ended December 31, 2014, our Adjusted EBITDA was €67.0 million and Adjusted EBITDA
margin was 7.3%. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2018, Adjusted EBITDA was €128.2 million and
Adjusted EBITDA margin was 9.3%.

**Our strengths**

**_Growing, resilient and highly visible Western European light vehicle distribution core aftermarket, with IAMs_**
**_outperforming the overall market_**

We operate in the Western European light vehicle distribution core aftermarket, which has forecasted
revenue growth of 1% to 3% over the 2017 to 2022 period. Within this market, the IAMs in which we operate
show particular strength and growth potential due to two long-term market dynamics: the stable, slightly
increasing Western European car parc and an increase in average vehicle age are expected to drive growth in the
number of cars that can be serviced by light vehicle IAM distributors like us in the coming years. Additionally,
increasing vehicle complexity and computerization of car systems is expected to drive increased prices and job
frequency.

In addition, the Western European light vehicle IAM tends to be resilient in the face of macroeconomic
factors that impact the automotive industry and distribution markets generally. While new car sales tend to
fluctuate with economic cycles, the light vehicle distribution core aftermarket benefits from a slightly but
steadily growing installed car parc, due to the ongoing need for repairs to be made on the existing car parc
regardless of downturns in the economy. For example, even when new car purchases declined in France
following the financial crisis (from approximately 2.2 million in 2009 to approximately 1.8 million in 2014), the
French car parc and the French light vehicle spare parts market continued to grow steadily in size because new
car sales only account for a small portion of the overall car parc. Approximately 2.1 million new cars were sold
in France in 2017, compared with a car parc of approximately 40 million cars in total. The light vehicle IAM is
also relatively less affected by economic downturns because, as new car sales decrease, the existing car parc’s
age and mileage increase, thereby increasing the need for maintenance and repair. In economic downturns
customers are more price-sensitive, and IAMs distributors, such as us, are generally more price-competitive than
OE car dealer networks.

Light vehicle IAM distributors also have the benefit of a high level of visibility in terms of the future
addressable market of cars needing service and repair. The addressable market for the light vehicle IAM is cars
aged over five years. Generally, cars aged under five years are covered by warranty and maintenance contracts
and are predominantly serviced by OE car dealer networks. As a result, we can project the size and composition
of the car parc that will require service in the five to ten-year range because parc size, vehicle types and installed
technology are known from the point of production. We generally service cars over a long period of time (from
five to twenty years), which may require multiple repairs and parts replacements over their lifespan.
Additionally, we distribute parts for cars that span the entire car parc, covering a wide range of makes and
models, and giving us a wider addressable market, as compared to our OE car dealer network competitors who
generally distribute parts for cars from just one manufacturer.

Moreover, we are able to offer lower prices than our OEM counterparts as IAM spare parts prices are on
average 30% lower than those of equivalent OEM-branded spare parts. Furthermore, in France, T-1 technicians
working for our distributor customers cost on average €45 to €60 per hour, while equivalent technicians working
for an OEM distributor would cost on average €70 to €110 per hour (depending on location). We therefore
benefit from being on average 30% less expensive than our OEM counterparts, both from the standpoint of
product prices and of labor costs, which we believe makes us the preferred solution for end-customers,
particularly after their original car warranty has expired.

As a result of the factors described above, growth of the light vehicle IAM is forecast to exceed or be on par
with the growth of the light vehicle distribution core aftermarket on the whole, for all of Western Europe and also
on a country by country basis, for the 2017 to 2022 period. The Western European light vehicle IAM has
historically outperformed both the broader market and its OE car dealer network competitors, a trend which is

expected to continue in the 2017 to 2022 period. Between 2014 and 2017, the Western European light vehicle

**_A leading independent B2B and B2C (DIY) spare parts distributor strongly positioned in the attractive_**

We are the market leader in the light vehicle IAM in France, with the largest independent single-branded
distribution network and 29% market share (in terms of revenue) in 2017, and in the truck IAM in France, with
the largest independent distribution network and 18% market share (in terms of revenue) in 2017. We also hold

in both Belgium and Italy and the fourth largest light vehicle IAM distributor in the Netherlands. We believe that

In addition to the Western European market being highly attractive, there are barriers to entry in the Western
European light vehicle distribution core aftermarket and scale benefits favor larger distributors. These barriers to
entry include the extensive logistics, technology and network investments that are necessary to service a broad
and fragmented customer base seeking supply of several million SKUs for rapid and continuous delivery and the
difficulty in building sufficient brand awareness and long-term relationships with suppliers that are necessary to
negotiate competitive pricing. Additionally, the Western European light vehicle distribution core aftermarket is
fragmented, with significant potential for consolidation, giving an edge to large distributors, such as us, who are
able to service the entire value chain and make strategic acquisitions.

We have outperformed the French light vehicle distribution core aftermarket and the light vehicle IAM in

**_Operational excellence based on a fully-integrated multi-channel distribution model with full control over the_**
**_value chain, offering superior product availability and best-in-class delivery times_**

We offer best-in-class product selection, availability and delivery times, giving us a significant advantage
over our competitors. We focus on delivering “the right product to the right place at the right time” relying on
our fully-integrated, multi-channel distribution model which is grounded in our extensive distribution network.

We are fully integrated, allowing us to control the value chain from suppliers, through logistics and
distribution, to end-customers. We are strongly and uniquely positioned as a central distribution intermediary for
all value chain levels, acting as an important link between parts suppliers and customers. We have built longterm relationships and enjoy significant purchasing power with a strategically concentrated group of suppliers,
resulting in excellent purchasing conditions for our CPUs. Through this supplier concentration strategy, we have
rationalized our supplier relationships, reducing our number of suppliers from 293 in 2010 to approximately 260
in 2018, allowing us to negotiate better terms with this smaller group of suppliers. For example, between 2014
and 2017, we reduced the number of suppliers of our brake product (the largest product family that we distribute)
from four to two. Over the 2014 to 2017 period, purchase volumes with brake product suppliers increased by
52%, growing from €21 million to €32 million, while our fees increased by 61%, growing from €10 million to
€16 million. Our offering is also multi-channel, with distribution carried out by a variety of wholly-owned
distributors, AD-affiliated distributors and local wholesale distributors who distribute our products to a variety of
customers, including AD-branded garages, independent garages, retail locations and online players. Since the
acquisition of Oscaro in November 2018, we also benefit from a direct access to end-customers through online
sales of new spare parts from manufacturers and wholesalers. Oscaro offers approximately one million SKUs
across the spare parts universe.

We then use our state-of-the-art logistics platforms and our extensive distribution network to deliver our
products with best-in-class delivery times to more than 70,000 regular professional customers. Our distribution
network is key to our ability to deliver superior product availability and delivery times and we have built a
distribution network that gives us strong coverage and capacity. In France in 2017, we operated the largest
independent, single-branded light vehicle spare parts distribution network and the largest truck spare parts
distribution and service network, with approximately 445 distribution and repair locations overall as of
December 31, 2017.

Our distribution model helps us lower our costs and allows us to stock an extensive range of products with
favorable prices and volumes from our suppliers. This approach also leads to high customer loyalty and gain
market share. On one hand, through our highly efficient logistics platforms and ability to designate single
delivery points, suppliers benefit from cost-efficient access to a highly fragmented customer base which they
would otherwise struggle to address themselves. On the other hand, customers benefit from having access to a
product portfolio that reflects the full range of suppliers and products at competitive prices and from best-in-class
delivery times.

**_A performing operational model supported by an extensive and diversified product and value-added services_**

We combine our powerful purchasing, logistical and distribution model with an extensive product and

acquisition of Oscaro enabled us to further diversify our business model by developing our online distribution

With over 55 years of experience in our industry, we have built the relationships, infrastructure and

Our organic growth has been supported by various factors, such as our new distribution model (which has

(such as web dealers), our successful recruiting of new branded garages, the development of our private-label
offers, improved purchasing conditions obtained through our supplier concentration strategy and our network
optimization strategy which is focused on cost-control. In recent years we have demonstrated stable organic
growth overall, particularly in the resilient light vehicle IAM, as a result of good purchasing conditions with
suppliers, network rationalization, recruitment of approximately 100 AD branded garages (net) per year from
2010 to 2017 with a churn rate of less than 5% and the disposal of non-core assets. Our model is based in part on
the delivery of value-added services to both suppliers and customers. These value-added services not only
generate fees from suppliers but also promote loyalty from customers, helping us grow our market share.

In addition, we have a strong track record of pursuing value-enhancing acquisitions and successfully

**_A strong financial profile delivering an attractive combination of resilient growth, margin improvement, low_**

Since 2014, we have grown our revenue from €914 million in the year ended December 31, 2014, to

We operate a business model that requires a relatively low capital expenditure, using rented facilities
without needing to own or maintain extensive physical infrastructure. During the year ended December 31, 2017,
our capital expenditures amounted to 2.1% of our revenue (excluding Logisteo) and consisted of maintenance

low level of capital expenditures has been stable in recent years, with capital expenditure for the years ended
December 31, 2014, 2015 and 2016, at 2.0%, 2.3% and 2.1% of revenue, respectively (in each case excluding
Logisteo). Our low levels of maintenance capital expenditure requirements have allowed us to invest in our
business in order to maintain our leading market positions and improve operating efficiency, as well as achieve
deleveraging through EBITDA growth and cash generation.

Logisteo and pursuing successful expansion into new geographies, products and channels. We believe that the

**Our strategy**

Our strategy is to continue growing organically by leveraging our history of operational excellence that
focuses on offering a superior supplier and customer experience, to become the key consolidator in the
fragmented markets in which we operate by using our proven approach to M&A and to develop our online
segment and our position as a fully multi-channel player.

In terms of organic growth, we intend to grow revenues and continue to outperform the markets in which we
operate by continuing to apply and enhance our operational model based on a fully-integrated supply chain and
the distinctive suite of value-added digital and commercial services that we offer to our customers and suppliers.
We are in the process of optimizing this model and have a clear vision for ongoing improvements that are
designed to adapt our business to our evolving markets. In particular, we intend to capitalize on our value-added
services in order to differentiate ourselves from our competitors, increase customer loyalty and gain market
share.

In terms of M&A-led growth, we are focused on improving Adjusted EBITDA in terms of absolute value as
well as in terms of Adjusted EBITDA margin. In order to do this, we will put increasing focus on executing
value-accretive M&A transactions and successfully and efficiently integrating acquired businesses into the
Group.

In terms of our multi-channel approach, we intend to leverage the acquisition of Oscaro to continue to grow
our online product offering in France and in other markets and to strengthen our position in the B2C (DIY)
segment.

**_Continue integrating our upstream supply chain to solidify our market-leading position and expand margins_**

We operate a fully-integrated supply chain that connects our strategically concentrated group of suppliers to
our CPUs and state-of-the-art logistics platforms, through to an extensive distribution network that serves more
than 70,000 customers with deliveries several times per day and with best-in-class delivery times. We intend to
build on our history of operational excellence by continuing to integrate and rationalize our supply chain. We
believe this approach will help us maintain and further enhance our strong and unique positioning as a central
distribution intermediary for all value chain levels and to reinforce our role as an important link between parts
suppliers and customers. Based on the value that we have extracted from operational improvements in recent
years, we believe that continual improvements to our supply chain will contribute to increased market share and
expanded margins.


9


-----

We believe that our supply chain is key to our success because it helps us offer unique advantages to our
suppliers. For example, our increasing use of centralized, automated platforms simplifies suppliers own delivery
processes by offering a single delivery point. We believe that this single delivery point approach is a significant
and attractive advantage for our suppliers. We also offer suppliers a range of innovative value-added services
such as marketing tools and intelligence, online support tools, payment guarantees and a centralized invoicing
system with simplified back office support, all of which help suppliers grow their own business while creating
greater efficiencies through simplified tracking, delivery, monitoring and payment solutions. We believe that
these services represent advantages that are a “win-win” proposition for us and our suppliers, differentiating us
from our competitors.

In addition, we are pursuing increased integration of our supply chain, which is based on two flows of spare
parts: a “direct delivery flow” from suppliers to distributors and a “platform-based flow” through our logistics
platforms. In the year ended December 31, 2017, 62% of our products were distributed via our platform-based
flow, as compared with 18% in 2010, representing a marked improvement that we intend to pursue by further
developing our platform-based flow. This approach is expected to drive improved product availability and
delivery times while generating favorable financial conditions for us, due in part to the higher logistics fees
which we can apply in this context, and which we expect will lead to higher margins, as the logistics fees
received from suppliers generally exceed the related costs of operating the logistics platforms. This is particularly
applicable to our new, automated platforms, such as Logisteo, because these platforms generally offer a doubled
capacity for SKU stockage as well as doubled processing capacity, allowing us to offer more SKUs from a wider
range of product lines and suppliers. We will pursue this strategy by encouraging new suppliers to make
deliveries through the platform flow from the outset as well as by having existing supplies expand the breadth of
their range offered through our platform-based flow.

**_Continue concentrating supplier relationships in order to optimize purchasing conditions with key suppliers_**
**_and expanding our private label offerings, to increase profitable growth_**

We are currently implementing a supplier concentration strategy by which we have rationalized our supplier
relationships, reducing our number of suppliers from 293 in 2010 to approximately 260 in 2018. This approach
has allowed us to further improve our negotiating leverage with suppliers, driving more favorable purchasing
terms and increased volumes, while maintaining a sufficient number of suppliers to avoid undue reliance on
particular suppliers. Additionally, we are often a key client of our major suppliers, further increasing our
negotiating leverage.

This approach has already enabled us to concentrate a significant number of our purchasing relationships but
there remain certain product families and products that we continue to source from multiple suppliers. As a
result, we see further opportunities to concentrate our supply flows and plan to select no more than two or three
suppliers per product or sub-category of product in the near future. We expect that this strategy will continue to
enhance purchasing conditions for us, which in turn will improve product availability and profitability.

In addition, we intend to continue expanding our private label offerings, such as ISOTECH and Requal, in
both new geographies as well as the countries in which we already operate. We benefit from more attractive
margins on ISOTECH products as compared with third-party branded products. As a result, our expansion
strategy for our private label offerings is expected to optimize production costs, while increasing volumes sold
per SKU and allowing us to negotiate improved purchasing conditions with the suppliers of these products, in
turn leading to profitable growth through margin expansion.

**_Build on improved distribution models in both light vehicle and trucks to continue growing market share_**

In recent years, we have been systematically improving our distribution models for our Light Vehicle
France and Trucks segments, thereby complementing our supplier concentration strategy and strategic
investments in our automated logistics platforms. Through this strategy, we aim to improve operational
efficiency, enhance customer service, cover multiple regions with the use of small pivot sites, rationalize flows
and optimize inventory and warehousing, reflecting a focus on offering higher availability of more SKUs at the
regional level, while maintaining excellent delivery times.

For example, since 2014, we have redesigned and refined our Light Vehicle France distribution model,
moving from a large number of delivery sites acting as intermediaries between suppliers and our logistics
platforms and garage customers, to a more precisely deployed network of pivot sites that connects suppliers and
our logistics platforms with proximity and delivery sites, which are strategically located to address customer
demand. A key component of this strategy is our ongoing efforts to grow our affiliated network of garages. We


10


-----

expect that our new model will improve distributor performance with optimized inventory levels and SKU
availability and an increased ability to adapt our offer to local customer requirements, leading to an enhanced
customer experience. We continue to seek ways to optimize our operation and believe that in the current, second
phase of this operational re-design, which will be focused on fine-tuning the light vehicle distribution model, we
can further improve delivery times, quality of service and availability of products, each of which are expected to
help us gain greater market share in the geographies where we operate.

In our Trucks segment, we are also focused on operational improvement and have begun implementing a
new distribution model, which is expected to be fully rolled out by mid-2019. The new distribution model for the
Trucks segment aims to grow our network of affiliated garages and to reconfigure our current network of 130
distribution sites to be organized around 12 regional warehouses focused on distribution to local sites, owned and
independent garages and integrated workshops. We believe that our new distribution model for our Trucks
segment will lead to better availability of our wide range of SKUs, allowing us to better utilize our large network
and unique range of value-added services to meet customer demand. For example, with our new Trucks
distribution model, we believe we will be the only player in the French truck spare parts market able to serve our
full range of customers with twice daily deliveries made within four hours.

**_Expand our value-added services offering to customers, further differentiating the customer experience and_**
**_driving customer loyalty_**

We have developed an innovative and unique suite of value-added services for our customers, including
best-in-class delivery times, commercial support, training and technical support, a strong commercial concept
with integrated branding, business leads to key third-party providers and a wide variety of online and digital
tools. We believe that the variety and quality of the value-added services that we offer to customers increase
customer loyalty in part because such services help embed us within their customers operations, making us a key
partner in our customers’ success. In addition, this varied suite of value-added services also enable us to serve a
wide and diverse customer base with a wide range of evolving needs and demands.

Our digital services are a key factor that differentiate us from our competitors. We intend to continue
growing our digital offering in order to capitalize on this competitive advantage. For example, in November
2018, we acquired Oscaro, the leading online seller of light vehicle spare parts in France. This strategic
acquisition strengthened our online distribution channel and allowed us to become an “omni-channel”
aftermarket spare parts distributor in France.

In addition, we have developed proprietary B2B online tools to support our customers with state-of-the-art
online ordering capabilities, such as our proprietary online portals, Autossimo and Truckissimo. Our online
ordering portals improve our customers’ experience by offering a user-friendly portal for garages to search
through a large selection of spare parts, directly order parts online and obtain technical information about those
parts. In 2017, one-third of French garages were Autossimo customers, demonstrating the wide appeal of these
portals. Our online tools enhance integration, increasing customer loyalty and wallet share while reducing call
center and other related costs. We have also created ID Garages to increase visibility of our branded garages. ID
Garages is a website that allows customers to locate and compare garages and schedule service appointments
online. It is a “win-win” solution for us, as we retain a percentage of the fee quote, and for our garage customers,
who collect fees from business gained through the portal. We estimate that ID Garages has generated
approximately €700,000 in subscriptions and fees for us and generated approximately €4.2 million of revenue for
our garage customers in the year ended December 31, 2017.

We aim to constantly innovate by offering new and improved services and tools and using existing tools to
create future growth. For example, we intend to expand our ID Garages offering into Benelux and Italy, with the
goal of doubling the number of subscribers, increasing revenues derived from this service and becoming a key
reference in online bookings. We also intend to extend our partnerships with third parties such as insurers and
fleets and to expand our innovative AD Connect offering. In addition, we have started to reinforce our
partnership with Grup Eina, a strong technical platform that offers customers valuable training opportunities.

**_Continue optimizing our distribution network_**

We believe that our extensive distribution network is important to our present and continued success. In
order to preserve and expand this advantage profitably, we employ a cost-conscious approach to managing our
distribution network, constantly focusing on improving network efficiency and breadth of coverage, while
minimizing or eliminating redundancies wherever possible. For example, in our light vehicle business, we are
currently focused on ongoing upgrades to our real estate parc and improvements to the size and coverage of our


11


-----

footprint of distribution sites in France. When and where necessary, we remodel, close or consolidate sites. We
also work to lower and rationalize downstream logistics costs by maximizing the square footage of our sites and
by modernizing our logistics and monitoring functions, such as through the increased use of bar coding and the
creation of a dedicated logistics department. In our Trucks business, we are implementing an improvement plan
that is focused on closing low- and non-performing sites in the context of a broader profit-focused effort to
optimize our distribution network.

**_Continue to grow our footprint with entries into neighboring countries and expansion in existing countries_**

In recent years, we have implemented a number of successful acquisitions, demonstrating the strength and
rigor of our prudent M&A process. This M&A process is centered around careful evaluation of potential targets,
which are usually selected from local leaders that offer significant purchasing synergies. Through strategic
acquisitions, we have penetrated new geographies, as demonstrated by our acquisition of Doyen Auto, which
allowed us to expand into Benelux, as well as broaden our reach or product offering in the countries in which we
already operate, as demonstrated by our acquisition of Mondial Pare-Brise, which allowed us to offer a full range
of windscreen replacement products in France. In addition, through the acquisition of Oscaro in France, we have
penetrated the B2C (DIY) segment and strengthened our position in the e-commerce market. We have started to
implement the following initiatives to bring back Oscaro’s sales and profitability to normalized levels: (i) put in
place an interim management team with full control on the operations of the business, who have already started
to deliver our profitability improvement plan for Oscaro, (ii) the payment of supplier overdues and client refunds,
which we aim to finalize during the first quarter of 2019, (iii) various cost-saving measures, including the
carve-out of non-core activities, change of service provider and renegotiation of transportation costs, as well as
some pre-identified savings on consulting fees and the rationalization of international activities, (iv) negotiations
with suppliers in order to optimize purchasing terms and conditions, which we aim to finalize during the first half
of 2019 and (v) sales improvement through customers reimbursements to improve customer satisfaction,
ensuring that the full assortment of spare parts is available, online and offline marketing strategy and branding
campaigns.

We intend to continue making strategic, value-accretive acquisitions in the near term as well as in the
medium term, including in certain geographies adjacent to the countries in which we operate. We intend to focus
on new geographies where the car parcs are similar enough to those in which we are already active to realize
synergies and where we can effectively use our logistics platforms and distribution networks. We also intend to
consolidate our leadership in the countries where we are already present, building on areas of strength and taking
advantage of the fragmented nature of these markets. We also have set a goal of continuing to grow our market
share in France, maintaining and strengthening our leading position in both the light vehicle and truck IAMs.

**_Maintain a positive social environment to recruit and retain talent by focusing on development opportunities_**

We believe that attracting and retaining talented people is critical to our success and believe that the key to
attracting and retaining talented employees is offering development and growth opportunities in the context of a
positive social environment. We intend to maintain our strong corporate culture with a human resources strategy
that focuses on creating and sustaining an experienced, motivated and stable workforce. In order to do this, our
human resources strategy is, and will continue to be, organized around four pillars: (i) successful talent
recruitment, supported by marketing events, educational collaborations and digital initiatives, (ii) development of
employees through training partnerships, e-learning and talent appraisal and evaluation processes, (iii) a costefficient approach to benefits through payroll monitoring, unified compensation policies and favorable social
protection schemes and (iv) the development of a positive social environment through continuous improvement
of working conditions, investments in work spaces and workforce rationalization.

**The Refinancing**

**_General_**

On the Issue Date, the Issuer will issue the Senior Secured Notes offered hereby and use the proceeds of the
Offering: (i) to fund the Existing Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes Redemption; (ii) to repay all amounts
outstanding under the Revolving Credit Facility; (iii) for general corporate purposes; and (iv) to pay the fees and
expenses incurred in connection with the foregoing. See “Use of proceeds.”

The Offering and the application of the proceeds from the Offering are collectively referred to in this
Offering Memorandum as the “Refinancing.”

**_Existing Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes Redemption_**

Concurrently with, and conditioned on, the closing of the Offering, the Issuer will use a portion of the
proceeds of the Senior Secured Notes to redeem €72.0 million aggregate principal amount of its Existing Senior
Secured Floating Rate Notes. See “Use of proceeds.” Following the Existing Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes
Redemption, €443.0 million aggregate principal amount of Existing Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes will
remain outstanding.

**_Repayment of the Revolving Credit Facility_**

Concurrently with, and conditioned on, the closing of the Offering, we will repay the €90.0 million
outstanding under the Revolving Credit Facility with a portion of the proceeds of the Offering. See “Use of
_proceeds.”_

**Recent developments**

**_Acquisition of Verviers Freins_**

On October 31, 2018, we completed the acquisition of Verviers Freins by our subsidiary Doyen Auto.
Verviers Freins is a Belgian multi-brand distributor of mechanical parts, bodywork, paint, tools and garage
equipment and was established in 1967. Verviers Freins operates in the Liège region and in eastern Belgium and
employs approximately 100 people in eight sale outlets.

**_Acquisition of Oscaro_**

In July 2018, we acquired a 4.95% ownership stake in Oscaro for consideration of €10 million. On
November 13, 2018, we increased our total ownership stake in Oscaro to 82.49% for incremental consideration
of approximately €80 million, which included a capital investment of approximately €55 million in Oscaro. We
financed the acquisition of Oscaro with drawings under our Revolving Credit Facility. Indenoï, the holding
company of Oscaro’s founder Pierre-Noël Luiggi, will retain a share of up to approximately 17.5% in Oscaro.
Mr. Luiggi will not continue to hold any operational role in the company.

Oscaro is an independent online distributor of light vehicle spare parts and was established in 2001. It is the
leader in online sales of light vehicle spare parts in France, which is the fastest growing independent aftermarket
distribution channel, and has an online market share of approximately 50% in France based on online sales.
Oscaro’s e-commerce platform allows car owners to buy automotive parts online from a range of manufacturers,
without going through automotive dealers. Oscaro’s product offering includes new spare parts from
manufacturers and wholesalers which include Bosch, Continental, Contiteck, Luk, SKF, TRW and Valeo, and we
have been one of the key spare parts suppliers of Oscaro. Oscaro generates revenue primarily from its B2C (DIY)
segment and operates mainly in France and, to a lesser extent, in other markets such as Spain. Oscaro served
approximately 2.5 million customers in 2017, received approximately 345,000 orders a month and had a portfolio
of approximately 1 million SKUs.


13


-----

Oscaro generated revenue of approximately €325 million and a negative EBITDA of approximately
€18 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, with a gross margin of approximately 30%. As of
September 30, 2018, Oscaro had €12.0 million of third-party borrowings outstanding under bilateral facilities and
finance leases, which we acquired in connection with the acquisition.

Since the completion of the acquisition, we have started to implement the following initiatives to bring back
Oscaro’s sales and profitability to normalized levels: (i) put in place an interim management team with full
control on the operations of the business, who have already started to deliver our profitability improvement plan
for Oscaro, (ii) the payment of supplier overdues and client refunds, which we aim to finalize during the first
quarter of 2019, (iii) various cost-saving measures, including the carve-out of non-core activities, change of
service provider and renegotiation of transportation costs, as well as some pre-identified savings on consulting
fees and the rationalization of international activities, (iv) negotiations with suppliers in order to optimize
purchasing terms and conditions, which we aim to finalize during the first half of 2019 and (v) sales
improvement through customers reimbursements to improve customer satisfaction, ensuring that the full
assortment of spare parts is available, online and offline marketing strategy and branding campaigns. We expect
to realize approximately €15 million of cost savings from optimization measures, including the rationalization of
non-core entities, and approximately €15 million purchasing synergies, resulting from Oscaro purchasing spare
parts under our existing arrangements with suppliers, which provide for better commercial terms. These savings
initiatives are expected to be implemented over the next 14 to 18 months and the implementation is expected to
cost approximately €10 million.

**_Change of Name_**

On November 22, 2018, the Issuer (formerly Autodis S.A.) announced that it changed its name to Parts
Europe S.A.

**_Bridge Facility Agreement_**

On January 2, 2019, we entered into a Bridge Facility Agreement among, inter alios, the Issuer and the
Parent Guarantor, BNP Paribas S.A. and Goldman Sachs International as arrangers and Elavon Financial
Services DAC, UK Branch, as agent (the “Bridge Facility Agreement”). We have an aggregate principal amount
of €90.0 million available for borrowing under the Bridge Facility Agreement on a committed basis to refinance
amounts drawn under our Revolving Credit Facility. The Bridge Facility Agreement may, subject to the
satisfaction of customary conditions precedent, be utilized until April 15, 2019. We expect the Bridge Facility
Agreement to be undrawn on the Issue Date. The Bridge Facility Agreement will terminate on or around the
Issue Date.

**_Current trading_**

Based on the preliminary draft of our internal management accounts, we currently expect our revenues to
increase by 15% to approximately €1,329 million for the eleven months ended November 30, 2018, of which
organic growth represents approximately 4% compared to the eleven months ended November 30, 2017. We also
expect our Adjusted EBITDA to increase by 14% to approximately €128 million for the eleven months ended
November 30, 2018 (without taking into account the acquisition of Oscaro), of which organic growth represents
approximately 5% compared to the eleven months ended November 30, 2017. We estimate that our cash
conversion rate was approximately 78% for the eleven months ended November 30, 2018. Our change in
working capital for that period resulted in a cash outflow of approximately €27 million and our capital
expenditures amounted to approximately €28 million. As of November 30, 2018, we had cash and cash
equivalents of approximately €85 million.

As of and for the twelve months ended September 30, 2018, the Issuer
and the Guarantors (excluding equity investments in wholly-owned
subsidiaries and intercompany receivables and loans) accounted for
33.5% of the consolidated total assets, 6.1% of the consolidated
revenue and 33.3% of the consolidated EBITDA of the Parent
Guarantor.

The obligations of a Guarantor under its Guarantee will be limited as
necessary to prevent the relevant Guarantee from constituting a
fraudulent conveyance or unlawful financial assistance under
applicable law, or otherwise reflect limitations under applicable law.
By virtue of these limitations, a Guarantor’s obligation under its
Guarantee could be significantly less than amounts payable with
respect to the Senior Secured Notes, or a Guarantor may have
effectively no obligation under its Guarantee. In particular, the
Guarantee of the Subsidiary Guarantor is expected to be limited in
value to an amount not greater than the outstanding amount under
certain proceeds loans, which is currently €282 million and
corresponds to the aggregate of the proceeds loan made available to
on-lend the proceeds of prior issuances of the Existing Senior Secured
Notes to the Subsidiary Guarantor. Other indebtedness of the
Guarantors may not be similarly limited. See “Risk factors—Risks
_related to our indebtedness and the Senior Secured Notes—Corporate_
_benefit, financial assistance laws and other limitations on the_
_Guarantors or the Luxembourg Security Providers may adversely_
_affect the validity and enforceability of the Guarantees of the Senior_
_Secured Notes or security interests in the Collateral” and “Risk_
_factors—Risks related to our indebtedness and the Senior Secured_
_Notes—The insolvency and administrative laws of France and_
_Luxembourg, as the case may be, may not be favorable to creditors,_
_including investors in the Senior Secured Notes, and may limit your_
_ability to enforce your rights under the Senior Secured Notes, the_
_Guarantees or the security interests in the Collateral.” The validity_
and enforceability of the Guarantees and the liability of each
Guarantor will be subject to the limitations described in “Certain
_insolvency law considerations and limitations on the validity and_
_enforceability of the Guarantees and the security interests.”_

Agreement. Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement,

and certain future indebtedness and hedging obligations permitted
under the terms of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture and the
Intercreditor Agreement to rank pari passu with indebtedness under
the Revolving Credit Facility in priority to the Senior Secured Notes
and the Guarantees in respect of the Senior Secured Notes. See

_Agreement.” The Guarantees will be subject to release under certain_
circumstances. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Notes
_Guarantees release.”_

**Security . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Senior Secured Notes will be secured by: (i) a first-priority
pledge of the share capital of LuxCo 6 held by LuxCo 5; (ii) a firstpriority pledge of the capital stock, material bank accounts and
material intragroup receivables of the Parent Guarantor; (iii) a firstpriority pledge of the capital stock of the Issuer (other than certain de
_minimis shareholdings); (iv) first-priority security interests over_
certain assets of the Issuer, including the capital stock of
Autodistribution S.A.S., Magenta Auto Pièces S.A. and SDFM S.A.
held by the Issuer, its material bank accounts and its material
intragroup receivables; and (v) a first-priority pledge of (A) the
capital stock of Commerce Rechange Automobiles S.A.S., Cofirhad
S.A.S. and AD Grand Ouest S.A.S. held by Autodistribution S.A.S.,
(B) Autodistribution S.A.S.’s material bank accounts and
(C) Autodistribution S.A.S.’s material intragroup receivables. See
“Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Security.”

The Revolving Credit Facility and future hedging obligations (if any)
(the “Super Senior Obligations”) are secured by first-priority security
interests over, among other things, the Collateral, contractually
ranking pari passu with the security interests securing the Senior
Secured Notes. Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, in the
event of enforcement of the security interests over the Collateral,
holders of Senior Secured Notes will receive proceeds from the
Collateral only after the Super Senior Obligations have been repaid.
The security interests in the Collateral are limited as necessary to
recognize certain limitations arising under or imposed by local law
and defenses generally available to providers of Collateral (including
those that relate to fraudulent conveyance or transfer, voidable
preference, financial assistance, corporate purpose or benefit, capital
maintenance or similar laws, regulations or defenses affecting the
rights of creditors generally) or other considerations under applicable
law. For a brief description of such limitations, see “Certain
_insolvency law considerations and limitations on the validity and_
_enforceability of the Guarantees and the security interests.”_

**Intercreditor Agreement . . . . . . . . . .** Pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement, the first-priority security
interests securing the Senior Secured Notes are contractually deemed
to rank equally with the security interests that secure (but only to the
extent that such security is expressed to secure those liabilities) (i)
obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility, (ii) certain
obligations under hedging arrangements and (iii) certain other future
indebtedness permitted to be incurred under the Senior Secured Notes
Indenture (including to the extent such indebtedness shares in these
security interests, future subordinated notes). Such security interests
are, or will be, evidenced by security documents for the benefit of


20


-----

(whether directly or through the Security Agent) the holders of the
Senior Secured Notes, the lenders under the Revolving Credit Facility
and/or the holders of certain other future senior or subordinated
indebtedness and obligations. Under the terms of the Intercreditor
Agreement, subject to certain conditions, in the event of acceleration
of the Revolving Credit Facility, the Senior Secured Notes, amounts
recovered in respect of the Senior Secured Notes, including from the
enforcement of the Guarantees or the Collateral, will be required to
repay indebtedness in respect of the Revolving Credit Facility, certain
future indebtedness permitted under the terms of the Senior Secured
Notes Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement to rank pari passu
with the Revolving Credit Facility and future hedging obligations (if
any) in priority to the Senior Secured Notes, following the payment of
fees and expenses of the agent under the Revolving Credit Facility,
the Trustee and the Security Agent (and any receiver or delegate) and
any fees and expenses of any other creditor representative of future
senior or subordinated indebtedness permitted under the terms of the
Senior Secured Notes Indenture to benefit from such security
interests.

The Security Agent may refrain from enforcing the relevant security
unless instructed by the relevant Instructing Group (as defined in the
Intercreditor Agreement). The relevant Instructing Group or such
other class of creditors as specified by the Intercreditor Agreement
may, under certain conditions, be entitled to instruct the Security
Agent to enforce the relevant security subject to, and in accordance
with, the provisions of the Intercreditor Agreement. In the event of
conflicting instructions, the Intercreditor Agreement contains
provisions as to which set of instructions will prevail. See
“Description _of_ _certain_ _financing_ _arrangements—Intercreditor_
_Agreement.”_

**Optional redemption . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Issuer may redeem all or part of the Senior Secured Notes at the
redemption prices set forth under “Description of the Senior Secured
_Notes—Optional redemption,” plus accrued and unpaid interest and_
additional amounts, if any, to, but not including, the date of
redemption.

**Additional amounts; Tax**
**redemption** . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . The Issuer may redeem the Senior Secured Notes in whole, but not in
part, at any time, upon giving prior notice, if, as a result of certain
changes in tax law the Issuer or Guarantor is or would be required to
pay additional amounts with respect to the Senior Secured Notes. If
the Issuer decides to exercise such redemption right, it must pay a
price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Senior Secured
Notes plus interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but not
including, the date of redemption. See “Description of the Senior
_Secured Notes.”_

**Change of control** . . . . . . . . . . . . . . If the Issuer experiences a change of control, the holders of the Senior
Secured Notes will have the right to require the Issuer to offer to
repurchase the Senior Secured Notes at 101% of their principal
amount plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if
any, to, but not including, the date of such repurchase. A change of
control, however, will not be deemed to have occurred if a
consolidated net senior secured leverage ratio is not exceeded in
connection with such event. See “Description of the Senior Secured
_Notes—Change of Control.”_

**Certain covenants . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Issuer will issue the Senior Secured Notes under the Senior
Secured Notes Indenture. The Senior Secured Notes Indenture will
limit, among other things, the ability of the Parent Guarantor, the
Issuer and the restricted subsidiaries of the Issuer to:

                         - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain
preferred stock;

                         - pay dividends, redeem capital stock and make certain
investments;

                         - enter into certain transactions with affiliates;

                         - create or permit to exist certain security interests;

                         - impose restrictions on the ability of our subsidiaries to pay
dividends or make other payments to us;

                         - transfer, lease or sell certain assets, including subsidiary stock;

                         - merge or consolidate with other entities;

                         - amend certain documents; and

                         - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the
Senior Secured Notes.

Additionally, the Senior Secured Notes Indenture will limit the ability
of LuxCo 5, LuxCo 6, the Parent Guarantor and the Issuer to engage
in certain business and other activities.

Each of these covenants is subject to a number of significant
exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the Senior Secured
_Notes—Certain covenants,” and the related definitions._

Certain of the covenants will be suspended if and for as long as we
achieve investment-grade ratings and following a qualifying initial
public offering of the capital stock of any direct or indirect parent
entity of the Issuer. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—
_Certain covenants—Suspension of covenants on achievement of_
_Investment Grade Status,” and “Description of the Senior Secured_
_Notes—Certain covenants—Disapplication of covenants and release_
_of Liens on a Qualifying IPO.”_

**Use of proceeds . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** We intend to use the gross proceeds from the Offering: (i) to fund the
Existing Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes Redemption; (ii) to
repay all amounts outstanding under the Revolving Credit Facility;
(iii) for general corporate purposes; and (iv) to pay the fees and
expenses incurred in connection with the foregoing. See “—The
_Refinancing” and “Use of proceeds.”_

**Transfer restrictions** . . . . . . . . . . . . The Senior Secured Notes and the Guarantees have not been, and will
not be, registered under U.S. federal or state or any foreign security
laws and are subject to restrictions on resales. See “Important
_information_ _about_ _this_ _Offering_ _Memorandum,”_ “Transfer
_restrictions” and “Plan of distribution.” We are under no obligation,_
and we do not intend, to register the Senior Secured Notes in the
United States under the U.S. Securities Act.

**Listing . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Application will be made to the Authority for the listing of and
permission to deal in the Senior Secured Notes on the Official List of
the Exchange. There can be no assurance that the Senior Secured
Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that such
permission to deal in the Senior Secured Notes will be granted or that
such listing will be maintained.
