_IFRS 9—Financial instruments_

We adopted IFRS 9 on January 1, 2018, prospectively. The comparative periods presented have not been
restated to reflect the potential impact. Under IFRS 9, we applied the simplified approach permitted thereby,
which requires expected lifetime losses to be recognized at the initial recognition of the receivables. For
receivables of our major customers, a probability-weighted estimate of credit losses is recognized based on each
customer’s credit ratings. For other receivables, a portfolio approach is applied to the extent they have similar
credit risk characteristics and provision is recognized according to certain criteria based on days past due of the
receivables and actual historical default rates. The impact of the first adoption of IFRS 9 on our consolidated
statement of financial position as of January 1, 2018, is described in note 5.4 to the unaudited interim condensed
consolidated financial statements of the Parent Guarantor as of and for the nine months ended September 30,
2018.

**Explanation of key income statement line items**

The following is a brief description of the revenue and expenses that are included in the line items of our
income statement.

76


-----

**_Revenue_**

Revenue is recognized when we satisfy a performance obligation by transferring a promised good or service
to the customer. An asset is transferred when the customer obtains control of that asset. The revenue can be
broken down as follows:

   - _Sales revenue through our logistics platforms: We operate a distribution of spare parts for light_
vehicles and trucks, based on a highly sophisticated distribution system that requires significant
investments in logistics.

   - _Direct flow sales commission: We also sell spare parts, equipment and tools that are delivered directly_
by suppliers to independent distributors and do not pass through our logistics platforms. When such
third party suppliers other than us are involved in providing goods to a customer, we assess whether the
nature of our promise to the customer is a performance obligation to provide the specified goods itself
or to arrange for the suppliers to provide those goods or services. We are considered an agent if our
performance obligation is to arrange for the provision of goods by the suppliers and revenue is
recognized for the amount of any commission to which we expect to be entitled in exchange for
arranging for the suppliers to provide our goods. The commission revenue recognized corresponds to
the difference between the consideration received from the customer less the consideration due to the
supplier that provided the goods. Where direct delivery is made by suppliers to independent
distributors, we are invoiced by suppliers and then invoices such distributors. Related payment flows
are processed by us.

**_Cost of goods sold_**

Cost of goods sold includes purchases of goods, supplier rebates, change in inventories and net allocation to
inventories depreciation.

**_Personnel costs_**

Personnel costs include wages, social security contributions, profit-sharing plans and pension costs. Pension
costs include the allocation to provisions for retirement benefits for the year as well as the reversal of provisions
as a result of benefits paid during the year. Personnel costs also include the CICE and the “Fillon” tax reduction,
which are deducted from personnel costs.

**_External expenses_**

External expenses relate to non-direct operating costs, including rental expenses, shipping expenses,
maintenance and repair costs, legal and other fees, IT expenses, advertising expenses, subcontracting costs,
travelling and other expenses.

**_Taxes other than income taxes_**

Taxes other than income taxes include taxes on salaries (mainly taxes in respect of vocational training), the
social construction tax (Participation à l’effort de construction), the real estate business contribution (Cotisation
_foncière des entreprises), the social solidarity contribution (Contribution sociale de solidarité des sociétés, a tax_
calculated based on a percentage of revenue) and other taxes other than income tax.

**_Other operating income and expenses_**

Other operating income and expenses include other items related to our ordinary activities, such as losses
for doubtful accounts and service fees related to B2B websites for electronic catalogues, and commissions paid
and received as part of the service connecting insurers and vehicle repairers.

**_Depreciation/amortization expenses_**

Depreciation expenses represent the depreciation of property, plant and equipment. Amortization relates to
intangible assets, excluding goodwill and brands, such as AD. Assets are depreciated over their estimated useful
lives.

**_Other income and expenses from operations_**

Other income and expenses from operations generally relate to one-off events or other events outside
ordinary business. Other income and expenses from operations can include gains and losses on the disposal of

77


-----

operations, of property, plant and equipment and intangible assets, as well as costs relating to provisions and
expenses relating to significant and unusual restructuring, employee and tax disputes and impairment losses/
reversals on goodwill and brands, including AD and costs related to major acquisitions and to our previously
contemplated initial public offering.

**_Financial income and expenses_**

Financial income includes income from financial investments, foreign exchange gains and other financial
income. Financial expenses include interest on external loans and bank overdrafts payable by us, discounting of
borrowings and debt, expenses related to financial instruments and to finance leases, foreign exchange losses and
other financial expenses.

**_Income tax_**

Income taxes consist of current tax expense, CVAE (Cotisation sur la Valeur Ajoutée des Entreprises) and
changes in deferred tax assets.

**Description of other key financial indicators**

**_Adjusted EBITDA_**

“Adjusted EBITDA” is defined as operating income from ordinary activities before depreciation and
amortization expenses adjusted for certain items that we consider to be non-recurring or exceptional in nature, or
otherwise not reflective of the ongoing performance of our business. See the table set forth in “Summary—
_Summary consolidated financial and other information” for a reconciliation of operating income from ordinary_
activities and Adjusted EBITDA to net income/(loss) from continuing operations for the nine months ended
September 30, 2017 and 2018, and the years ended December 31, 2015, December 31, 2016 and December 31,
2017.

**Restatements**

**_IFRS 15—Revenue recognition_**

We elected to early adopt IFRS 15 as of January 1, 2017, relating to revenue recognition from contracts with
customers, using the full retrospective method, which requires restatement of each prior reporting period
presented. We applied this full retrospective method to restate our financial statements for the two years ended
December 31, 2015 and 2016. The most significant impact of the IFRS 15 standard relates to the sales of spare
parts, equipment and tools delivered directly by suppliers to independent distributors that do not transit through
our logistics platforms as they are directly delivered by suppliers to independent distributors (referred to as direct
sales transactions). Historically under IAS 18 we bear the inventory and credit risks of these products and
therefore are considered a principal in these transactions. Under IFRS 15, the guidance focuses on the transfer of
control of the products rather than the risks and, accordingly, we are considered an agent, rather than the
principal in those transactions. Therefore for the direct sales transactions, only the net amount that we retain as a
commission is recognized as revenue. This accounting better reflects our strategy to focus on transactions
involving our logistics platforms rather than direct flow transactions which do not pass through our platforms.
The IFRS 15 impacts that we have identified are mainly driven by the new principal versus agent application
guidance as explained above.

The adoption of IFRS 15 resulted in a reversal of cost of goods sold for purchase of goods from the
suppliers and a corresponding reversal of revenue previously recognized for direct sales to distributors for the
same amount. The remaining revenue represents the commission we earned for direct sales transactions,
including discounts received from suppliers and discounts given to the distributors. The adoption therefore had
no impact on our EBITDA or operating income in any reporting period and had no impact on the consolidated
reserves as of January 1, 2017. Adoption of the standard also did not impact the assets and liabilities on the
consolidated statement of financial position nor cash from or used in operating, financing, or investing on the
consolidated statement of cash flows. Restatements to the previously reported results due to the adoption of the
new standard on our consolidated income statements are described in note 4 to the audited consolidated financial
statements of the Parent Guarantor as of and for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015, included in
this Offering Memorandum.

**_IFRS 5—Discontinued operations_**

On August 4, 2017, we entered into an agreement for the sale of our subsidiary in Poland, AD Polska. AD
Polska was classified as discontinued operations in the unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial
statements as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2017, and in the consolidated financial statements
for the year ended December 31, 2017. In accordance with the requirements of IFRS, our consolidated income
statements for years ended December 31, 2015 and 2016 have been restated to exclude the impact of the disposed
business. Restatements to the previously reported results due to discontinued operations on our consolidated
income statements are described in note 4 to the audited consolidated financial statements of the Parent
Guarantor as of and for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2016 and 2017 included in this Offering
Memorandum.

**Segment reporting**

Throughout this Offering Memorandum, we present our financial results by segment. These segments
correspond to the Parent Guarantor’s reporting segments in accordance with IFRS 8 “Operating Segments.” Our
operating segments consist of the following:

   - _Light Vehicle France segment, which includes the activities of:_

(i) the CPUs dedicated to the supply of spare parts for Light Vehicle France to both our whollyowned distributors and our network of affiliated independent distributors;

(ii) Logisteo, a central automated warehouse from which spare parts for Light Vehicle France are
distributed, the other parts being supplied directly by the suppliers;

(iii) Cora, a logistics platform in France for spare parts for light vehicles, specialized in the body parts
business;

(iv) ACR, a logistical platform for spare parts for light vehicles, with a strong exposure to online
dealers;

(v) Mondial Pare-Brise, a specialist in the repair and replacement of windshields in France, acquired
in 2017;

(vi) our network of wholly-owned distributors in France, who sell light vehicle spare parts to garages
that provide repair and maintenance services for light vehicles; and

(vii) headquarters costs attributable to the Light Vehicle France segment.

   - _Trucks segment, which includes the activities of:_

(i) the CPUs, which are dedicated to the supply of spare parts for trucks to both our wholly-owned
distributors and our network of affiliated independent distributors;

(ii) Bremstar, a national platform for trucks;

(iii) our network of wholly-owned distributors in France selling spare parts for trucks to garages that
provide repair and maintenance services; and

(iv) headquarters costs attributable to the Trucks segment.

   - _Light Vehicle International segment, which includes the activities of:_

(i) the Doyen Auto Group, which distributes light vehicle spare parts to various customers, including
web dealers;

(ii) Autodis Italia, which owns several acquired Italian companies (including G-Group acquired in
June 2018); and

(iii) Geevers, since June 2018.

Our operations in Poland, sold in August 2017, have not been included in the Light Vehicle International
segment since the disposal thereof and are accounted for as discontinued operations in the financial statements
presented in this Offering Memorandum.

In the future, we will report Verviers Freins, acquired in October 2018, in our Light Vehicle International
segment and we will report Oscaro, acquired in November 2018, in a new, separate segment.

Revenue increased by €124.4 million, or 13.4%, from €930.9 million for the nine months ended
September 30, 2017, to €1,055.3 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, mainly due to the
expansion of operations through acquisitions in France, Benelux and Italy.

   - Light Vehicle France: Light Vehicle France revenue increased by €29.3 million, or 4.5%, from
€644.2 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2017, to €673.5 million for the nine months
ended September 30, 2018, mainly due to (i) the full impact of the acquisition of Mondial Pare-Brise
on March 22, 2017, (ii) the acquisition in 2018 of SFIA, GPR Auto and Vallespir Auto Diffusion S.à
r.l, which generated €1.5 million of revenue since their respective acquisition dates and (iii) organic
growth generated by gains in market shares mainly as a result of increased revenue from Affiliated
Distributors and an increase in our CPU revenue due to a larger product offering made available
through our new automated Logisteo platform (mechanical parts, painting and equipment), which
allows us to recognize the full amount of revenue, as we sell directly to customers rather than through
our distributors.

   - Trucks: Trucks revenue increased by €7.3 million, or 6.3%, from €116.3 million for the nine months
ended September 30, 2017, to €123.6 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, mainly

81


-----

due to (i) organic growth following the ongoing implementation of a new distribution model and
business re-organizational measures at the Group level; and (ii) the addition of new AD Poids Lourds
workshops generating additional sales.

   - Light Vehicle International: Light Vehicle International revenue increased by €87.8 million, or 51.5%,
from €170.4 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2017, to €258.2 million for the nine
months ended September 30, 2018, mainly due to the full-period effect of the acquisitions of Italian
distributors (OVAM, Ricauto and Topcar) in 2017 and the acquisitions of Geevers and G-Group in
2018.

_Cost of goods sold_

Cost of goods sold increased by €83.1 million, or 16.1%, from €516.3 million for the nine months ended
September 30, 2017, to €599.4 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, primarily due to higher
sales volume as a result of both acquisitions and organic growth. As a percentage of revenue, cost of goods sold
increased from 55.5% for the nine months ended September 30, 2017, to 56.8% for the nine months ended
September 30, 2018. This slight increase as a percentage of revenue was mainly due to a time lag in realizing
purchasing synergies from the recent acquisitions and the lower gross margins from the recently acquired Italian
businesses (taking into account the full-period impact from acquisitions completed in 2017 and the contribution
of acquisitions completed in 2018), partly offset by the full-period impact of Mondial Pare-Brise’s purchasing
synergies.

_Personnel costs_

Personnel costs increased by €16.2 million, or 8.0%, from €203.3 million for the nine months ended
September 30, 2017, to €219.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, mainly due to the
integration of OVAM, Topcar, Ricauto, Mondial Pare-Brise, G-Group and Geevers.

As a percentage of revenue, personnel costs decreased from 21.8% for the nine months ended September 30,
2017, to 20.8% for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, primarily due to (i) our productivity
improvements; and (ii) the effect of the acquisition of OVAM, Topcar, Ricauto and G-Group in Italy, which have
a lower personnel cost base than the Group’s average.

_External expenses_

External expenses increased by €15.1 million, or 12.3%, from €122.3 million for the nine months ended
September 30, 2017, to €137.4 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, mainly due to the effects
of (i) higher advertising expenses, which increased by €3.7 million between the relevant periods due to one-off
expenses related to a large-scale AD network conference held in September 2018 and (ii) higher transportation
costs, which increased by €3.9 million, between the relevant periods, as a result of higher activity, increasing fuel
costs and increasing cost of the transportation service companies. As a percentage of revenue, external expenses
slightly decreased from 13.1% for the nine months ended September 30, 2017, to 13.0% for the nine months
ended September 30, 2018. This decrease as a percentage of revenue was primarily due to (i) the effect of the
acquisition of OVAM, Topcar, Ricauto, and G-Group in Italy as well as Geevers, which have a lower external
expense cost base than the Group’s average; and (ii) our efforts to monitor and control external costs.

_Taxes other than income taxes_

Taxes other than income taxes remained stable at €9.3 million for the nine months ended September 30,
2017, and for the nine months ended September 30, 2018.

_Other operating income and expenses_

Other operating income decreased by €1.6 million, or 50.0%, from €3.2 million for the nine months ended
September 30, 2017, to €1.6 million for the nine months period ended September 30, 2018.

ended September 30, 2017, to €12.2 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, mainly due to (i)
€8.2 million costs related to our then contemplated initial public offering, including financial consulting costs as
incurred up to date; and (ii) an increase in IT transformation costs, from €0.5 million for the nine months ended
September 30, 2017 to €2.2 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2018. This increase was partly
offset by (i) the one-off costs related to the implementation of the new Logisteo platform in Réau for the nine
months ended September 30, 2017, which amounted to €3.5 million, and (ii) a decrease in fees related to
acquisitions, from €3.9 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2017, to €1.8 million for the nine
months ended September 30, 2018.

Revenue increased by €235.1 million, or 23.1%, from €1,019.7 million for the year ended December 31,
2016, to €1,254.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, primarily due to the OVAM, Ricauto, Topcar
and Doyen Auto acquisitions, reflected in our Light Vehicle International segment.

   - Light Vehicle France: Light Vehicle France revenue increased by €31.4 million, or 3.8%, from
€823.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €855.1 million for the year ended
December 31, 2017, primarily due to (i) the acquisition of Mondial Pare-Brise on March 22, 2017
which contributed, from the date of acquisition to the end of 2017, €21.9 million to our revenue; (ii) the
increase in revenue of the ACR (including Automax acquired in February 2016) platform by
€12.7 million, or 15.2%, driven by organic growth with web dealers, and the continuous effect of
marketing actions and loyalty programs that were launched with wholesalers, which had a favorable
effect on our business activity; (iii) the increase in our CPU revenue increase by €11.5 million, or
18.4%, driven by activity with Affiliated Distributors, mainly due to a better loyalty rate and an
increase in sales volumes, and the progressive ramp-up of sales of our private label ISOTECH sales;
and (iv) the increase in revenue generated by our Cora platform, €3.7 million, or 8.1%, supported by
continued growth of the windscreen sales, and sustained body parts sales. This increase was partially
offset by a decrease of organic sales by a limited subset of wholly-owned distributors due to
operational difficulties that we are currently addressing through our transformation plan.

   - Trucks: Trucks revenue increased by €2.3 million, or 1.5%, from €155.3 million for the year ended
December 31, 2016, to €157.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, primarily due to (i) the
improved performance of our wholly-owned subsidiaries; and (ii) the acquisition of Bisensang in
March 2017 which, for the year ended December 31, 2017, contributed €4.7 million to our revenue.
This increase was partially offset by the closure and sale of six integrated workshops in 2017.

   - Light Vehicle International: Light Vehicle International revenue increased by €201.4 million from
€40.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €242.1 million the year ended December 31,
2017, primarily due to (i) the full year impact of Doyen Auto for the year ended December 31, 2017,
compared to only one quarter impact for the year ended December 31, 2016, as we completed the
acquisition in September 2016, resulting in €127.7 million additional revenue for the year ended
December 2017; (ii) the acquisition by Doyen Auto of AD Belux in April 2017, and API Marne et
Aube (two auto parts distributors located in Eastern France) in March 2017, which overall contributed
€4.0 million to our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2017; and (iii) the acquisition of a stake in
three Italian distributors, OVAM, Topcar and Ricauto, in May 2017 to become Autodis Italia Holding
S.r.l., contributing €71.4 million to our revenue.

_Cost of goods sold_

Cost of goods sold increased by €146.3 million, or 26.4%, from €553.2 million for the year ended
December 31, 2016, to €699.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, primarily due to the integration of
OVAM, Topcar, Ricauto and Mondial Pare-Brise. As a percentage of revenue, cost of goods sold increased from
54.3% for the year ended December 31, 2016, to 55.7% for the year ended December 31, 2017. This increase as
percentage of revenue was mainly due to the acquisition of OVAM, Topcar, Ricauto, which had a higher cost
structure than the Group’s average, as the synergies did not have an impact in 2017, partially offset by the
synergies realized in 2017 following the acquisition of Doyen Auto in September 2016.

_Personnel costs_

Personnel costs increased by €35.7 million, or 14.9%, from €240.3 million for the year ended December 31,
2016, to €276.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, primarily due to (i) severance costs in connection
with the restructuring of our Light Vehicle France and Trucks segments, as part of our transformation plan;
(ii) an increase in temporary employment expenses of €4.3 million between the year ended December 31, 2016,
and the year ended December 31, 2017, partially driven by the one-off costs of the implementation of the new
Logisteo platform; and (iii) the acquisition of OVAM, Topcar, Ricauto and Mondial Pare-Brise.

As a percentage of revenue, personnel costs decreased from 23.6% for the year ended December 31, 2016,
to 22.0% for the year ended December 31, 2017. This decrease as a percentage of revenue was primarily due to
(i) continuing management efforts to rationalize personnel costs over the period, (ii) the full year effect of the
acquisition of Doyen Auto, which had a lower personnel cost base than the Group’s average, (iii) the
predominantly fixed cost structure of personnel costs in the context of an increase in organic revenue and (iv) the
effect of the CICE, the rate of which increased from 6% to 7% between the year ended December 31, 2016, and
the year ended December 31, 2017, leading to a favorable impact of €1.5 million.

86


-----

_External expenses_

External expenses increased by €30.2 million, or 22.2%, from €136.0 million for the year ended
December 31, 2016, to €166.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, primarily due to (i) the acquisitions
of OVAM, Topcar, Ricauto and Mondial Pare-Brise, as well as the full year effect of the acquisition of Doyen
Auto; (ii) costs related to the implementation of our transformation plan, such as legal fees, restructuring costs,
including early rent termination costs in connection with site closures, or advisory costs related to the financial
and capital transformation of the Group; and (iii) the costs related to the implementation of the new platform
Logisteo, mainly consisting of rental expenses.

However, as a percentage of revenue, external expenses remained stable, representing 13.3% for the year
ended December 31, 2016, and 13.2% for the year ended December 31, 2017, mainly due to the full year effect
of Doyen Auto, which has a relatively lower percentage of external expenses to revenue.

_Taxes other than income taxes_

Taxes other than income taxes increased by €2.9 million, or 35.4%, from €8.2 million for the year ended
December 31, 2016, to €11.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, mainly due to the increase in the
amount of French vocational training tax, social construction tax and social solidarity contributions.

_Other operating income and expenses_

Other operating income and expenses increased by €0.6 million, or 12.2%, from an income of €4.9 million
for the year ended December 31, 2016, to an income of €5.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2017,
mainly due to an increase in the commissions received from affiliated garages as part of the service connecting
insurers and vehicle repairers, partly offset by a decrease of the gain on disposals of fixed assets, arising from the
sale of APS Berwald in January 2016, which resulted in a €3.5 million disposal gain for the year ended
December 31, 2016.

Adjusted EBITDA increased by €25.4 million, or 27.4%, from €92.6 million for the year ended
December 31, 2016, to €118.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, primarily due to improvements in
our Light Vehicle France and Light Vehicle International segments, as described below.

   - Light Vehicle France: The Adjusted EBITDA of the Light Vehicle France segment increased by
€9.5 million, or 9.4%, from €101.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €110.6 million
for the year ended December 31, 2017, primarily due to (i) continuous improvements of purchasing
conditions through the CPUs, combined with a more integrated supply chain leading to margin
improvements, especially with our new automated logistics platform Logisteo; and (ii) the acquisition
of Mondial Pare-Brise in March 2017 which contributed €3.6 million to our Adjusted EBITDA, from
the date of acquisition to December 31, 2017. The Adjusted EBITDA margin of our Light Vehicle
France segment increased from 9.1% for the year ended December 31, 2016, to 9.4% for the year
ended December 31, 2017 which, in the context of gains in market share, reflects the impact of the
rationalization of the distribution network and productivity gains over the period.

   - Trucks: The Adjusted EBITDA of our Trucks segment increased by €1.6 million, from €(0.0) million
for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €1.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, and the
Adjusted EBITDA margin of our Trucks segment increased from 0.0% for the year ended
December 31, 2016, to 1.0% for the year ended December 31, 2017, in each case due to the
implementation of the transformation plan for our Trucks segment, partly offset by the dilutive effect
of the acquisition of Bisensang.

   - Light Vehicle International: The Adjusted EBITDA of the Light Vehicle International segment
increased by €16.0 million, from €1.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €17.7 million
for the year ended December 31, 2017, and the Adjusted EBITDA margin of the Light Vehicle
International segment increased from 4.2% for the year ended December 31, 2016, to 7.3% for the year
ended December 31, 2017, due to (i) the full year impact of Doyen Auto for the year ended
December 31, 2017, compared to only one quarter impact for the year ended December 31, 2016 (as
the acquisition was settled in September 2016) and the impact of the acquisitions of AD Belux and API
Marne et Aube (two auto parts international networks located in Eastern France) by Doyen Auto in
2017; and (ii) the acquisition of OVAM, Topcar and Ricauto in May 2017.

   - Headquarters: The Adjusted EBITDA of our Headquarters segment decreased by €1.7 million, or
16.7%, from €(10.2) million for the year ended December 31, 2016, to €(11.9) million for the year
ended December 31, 2017, primarily due to (i) the change of criteria used for slow moving inventory
valuation, resulting in a one-off reversal (non-cash) of depreciation in 2016 at the Group level; and
(ii) a cost increase (relatively limited in the context of the Group’s development, due to our control of
central costs).

_Other income from operations_

Other income from operations decreased by €19.7 million, or 96.6%, from €20.4 million for the year ended
December 31, 2016, to €0.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, due to (i) the reversal of an

88


-----

impairment of the Autodistribution brand, which resulted in a one-off gain of €12.9 million. An impairment tests
is carried out each year. It was assessed that the Autodistribution brand had regained popularity and that the
impairment had to be reversed. As of December 31, 2016, the impairment was fully reversed in 2016; (ii) gains
on the disposal of property, plant and equipment and intangible assets of €4.8 million, related to APS Berwald
business and the sale of distribution sites; (iii) a €1.5 million gain following the final settlement of a dispute
related to the acquisition of Finelist in the 1990s; and (iv) the reversal of a provision for risks of €1.2 million.

_Other expenses from operations_

Other expenses from operations increased by €3.5 million, from €9.9 million for the year ended
December 31, 2016, to €13.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, primarily due to (i) acquisition fees
related to the acquisitions OVAM, Topcar, Ricauto and Mondial Pare-Brise; (ii) a one-off service cost of
€2.7 million related to the alignment of the collective pension agreement of certain subsidiaries to our collective
agreement for the year ended December 31, 2017; (iii) costs incurred during the implementation of our new
automated light vehicle logistics platform; and (iv) IT costs related to our IT transformation plan. This increase
was partly offset other expenses from operations incurred in 2016. For the year ended December 31, 2016, we
recorded a goodwill impairment of our Trucks segment of €2.1 million as a result of the negative performance of
the product line relating to truck parts for maintenance and repairs. There was no such impairment for year ended
December 31, 2017.

Revenue increased by €51.1 million, or 5.3%, from €968.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2015,
to €1,019.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2016.

   - Light Vehicle France: Light Vehicle France revenue increased by €15.1 million, or 1.9%, from
€808.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2015, to €823.7 million for the year ended
December 31, 2016, primarily due to (i) the good performance of our Cora platform, whose revenue
increased by €6.5 million, or 16.7%, supported by continued growth of the windscreen activity; (ii) the
increase in revenue of our ACR platform of €3.4 million, or 4.7%, especially driven by web dealers and
new significant contracts with key accounts. Furthermore, marketing actions and loyalty programs
were launched with wholesalers, which had a favorable effect on the activity; (iii) the increase in
revenue from CPUs of €15.3 million, or 32.5%, driven by activity with Affiliated Distributors, mainly
due to a better loyalty rate and an increase in sales volumes; and (iv) the acquisition of Automax by
ACR in February 2016, which contributed €7.8 million to our consolidated revenue in 2016. This
overall increase was partially offset by (i) the €19.5 million decrease in external revenue following the
disposal of APS Berwald, a former wholly-owned distributor of spare parts for light vehicles that was

90


-----

sold to an affiliated independent distributor in January 2016. This decrease was partly compensated by
the recognition as external of the CPUs revenue to this newly affiliated independent distributor, which
is no longer eliminated at consolidation level; and (ii) a €4.8 million decrease, or 7.9%, of the whollyowned distributor Gobillot Rhône revenue, which was being reorganized.

   - Trucks: Trucks revenue decreased by €4.7 million, or 2.9%, from €160.0 million for the year ended
December 31, 2015, to €155.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, mainly due to
challenging market conditions following the decrease in new registrations since 2009. This decrease
was partially offset by the acquisition of EDS in July 2016, which contributed to €2.7 million revenue
in 2016.

   - Light Vehicle International: Light Vehicle International revenue increased by €40.7 million between
the year ended December 31, 2015, and the year ended December 31, 2016, solely due to the
acquisition of Doyen Auto in September 2016.

_Cost of goods sold_

Cost of goods sold increased by €34.4 million, or 6.6%, from €518.8 million for the year ended
December 31, 2015, to €553.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, due to the acquisition of Doyen
Auto, partially offset by the disposal of APS Berwald.

As a percentage of revenue, cost of goods sold increased from 53.7% for the year ended December 31,
2015, to 54.3% for the year ended December 31, 2016. This increase as a percentage of revenue was mainly due
to: (i) Doyen Auto’s lower historical margin, in line with what was anticipated at the time of the acquisition since
the effects of synergies were not yet observed in 2016, and due to Doyen Auto’s clients mix, which is mainly
composed of key accounts and wholesalers; and (ii) price pressure at ACR and Cora, as well as in the Trucks
segment, given the high level of competition in the industry in this period. This increase was partially offset by:
(i) the positive effect of the improvement in inventory turnover, following reduction plans in our subsidiaries and
a change in inventory depreciation criteria. In 2016, all distributors were required to reduce inventories for costsavings purposes in the context of the ramp-up of the platforms. In addition, we did an analysis our methodology
of depreciation of slow moving inventories, leading to a positive impact; and (ii) a higher level of supplier
rebates thanks to synergies following the Automax acquisition.

_Personnel costs_

Personnel costs were relatively stable for the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015 and were impacted
by the counter effects of the acquisition of Doyen Auto and the disposal of APS Berwal in 2016. As a percentage
of revenue, personnel costs decreased from 24.8% for the year ended December 31, 2015, to 23.6% for the year
ended December 31, 2016. This decrease as a percentage of revenue was primarily due to: (i) management efforts
to rationalize personnel costs over the period; (ii) the predominantly fixed cost structure of the personnel costs in
the context of an increase in organic revenue; and (iii) the Doyen Auto Acquisition, which had lower personnel
base cost than the Group’s average.

_External expenses_

External expenses increased by €12.0 million, or 9.7%, from €124.0 million for the year ended
December 31, 2015, to €136.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, due to the acquisition of Doyen
Auto, partially offset by the disposal of APS Berwald.

As a percentage of revenue, external expenses increased from 12.8% for the year ended December 31, 2015,
to 13.3% for the year ended December 31, 2016, primarily due to (i) the increase in shipping expenses of
€6.1 million, or 16.8%, between 2015 and 2016, mainly driven by the increase of Cora transportation costs due to
the development of the windscreen activity, which involves the use of specific transportation companies with
more expensive services. Furthermore, we had to deal with an increase in rates from carriers; (ii) an increase in
fees of €6.1 million, or 87.1%, related to the implementation of our transformation plan, such as legal fees,
restructuring costs or advisory costs related to the financial and capital transformation of the Group, and an
increase of sponsor fees following the latest leveraged buy-out of the Group; (iii) an increase in subcontracting
costs of €1.3 million, or 30.2%, driven by the new Logisteo platform, which contributed €1.0 million to the
increase in subcontracting costs between 2015 and 2016; and (iv) an increase in IT expenses of €1.2 million, or
16.0%. This change was partially offset by a €1.4 million net decrease, or 25.9%, in advertising expenses.
Advertising campaigns, especially on television, were launched in 2016, but most of the costs incurred were
passed on to distributors.

€8.7 million, or 9.4%, from €92.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2015, to €101.1 million for
the year ended December 31, 2016, and Adjusted EBITDA margin of the Light Vehicle France
segment increased from 11.4% for the year ended December 31, 2015, to 12.3% for the year ended
December 31, 2016. This increase as a percentage of revenue, in the context of significant gains in
market shares, was primarily due to (i) continuous improvements of purchasing conditions through our
CPUs, combined with a more integrated supply chain, leading to margin improvements, especially with
the new automated logistics platform Logisteo located in Réau; (ii) the rationalization of our
distribution network; and (iii) a lower level of fixed costs as a percentage of revenue in a context of
positive organic growth.

   - Trucks: The Adjusted EBITDA of the Trucks segment decreased by €2.8 million, from €2.8 million for
the year ended December 31, 2015, to €(0.0) million for the year ended December 31, 2016, and
Adjusted EBITDA margin of the Trucks segment decreased from 1.8% for the year ended
December 31, 2015, to 0.0% for the year ended December 31, 2016. These decreases were due to (i) a
slowdown in revenue in the context of challenging market conditions following a decrease in new
registrations since the beginning of the economic crisis; (ii) the lower management focus on our Trucks
segment during that period; and (iii) a number of underperforming workshop sites that required
turnaround. Those operational difficulties led us to implement a significant reorganization and profit
improvement plan of our Trucks segment, mainly over 2016 and 2017, through a geographical
repositioning of the distribution sites, a change in management and the closure of some
underperforming sites.

   - Light Vehicle International: The Adjusted EBITDA of the Light Vehicle International segment
increased by €1.7 million between the year ended December 31, 2015, and the year ended
December 31, 2016, solely due to the acquisition of Doyen Auto. The Adjusted EBITDA margin of the
Light Vehicle International segment was 4.2% in the year ended December 31, 2016, given that we had
not yet realized the synergies with Doyen Auto in 2016.

   - Headquarters: The Adjusted EBITDA of our Headquarters segment increased by €1.9 million, or
15.4%, from €(12.1) million for the year ended December 31, 2015, to €(10.2) million for the year
ended December 31, 2016, primarily due to a modification of the criteria for the calculation of our slow
moving inventory in 2016. This resulted in a one-off reversal (non-cash) of depreciation in 2016 at
Group level.

_Other income from operations_

Other income from operations increased by €19.0 million from €1.4 million for the year ended
December 31, 2015, to €20.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2016. In 2015, other income from
operations was exclusively composed of the reversal of a provision for risk for €1.4 million. In 2016, other
income from operations was mainly composed of (i) the reversal of an impairment of the Autodistribution brand
for €12.9 million which was booked in the early 2000s. An impairment test is carried out each year. In 2016 it
was assessed that the Autodistribution brand had regained popularity and that the impairment should be reversed.
As of December 31, 2016, the impairment was fully reversed; (ii) gains on the disposal of property, plant and
equipment and intangible assets for €4.8 million, related to the APS Berwald business and the proceeds of
distribution sites disposal; (iii) a €1.5 million income following the final settlement of a dispute related to the
acquisition of Finelist in the 1990s; and (iv) the reversal of a provision for risks for €1.2 million.

_Other expenses from operations_

Other expenses from operations increased by €4.0 million, or 67.8%, from €5.9 million for the year ended
December 31, 2015 to €9.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, mainly due to (i) a goodwill
impairment of €2.1 million related to the Trucks segment as a result of the negative performance of the truck
parts for maintenance and repairs product line; (ii) costs related to the implementation of our transformation plan,
such as legal fees, restructuring costs, including rental early termination costs in connection with site closures, or
advisory costs related to the financial and capital transformation of the Group, and severance costs; and
(iii) expenses related to the acquisition of Doyen Auto. This increase was partly offset by a decrease of
restructuring costs related to the Light Vehicle France segment in 2016, following the implementation of a new
distribution model and reorganizations in regions in 2015.

**Liquidity and capital resources**

Liquidity describes the ability of a company to generate sufficient cash flows to meet the cash requirements
of its business, including working capital needs, debt service obligations, capital expenditures, operating losses,
acquisitions, and contractual obligations and commitments. Our principal sources of liquidity have been our
existing cash and cash equivalents, cash generated from operations, factoring facilities, bank overdraft facilities
and finance leases.

We expect that our principal sources of liquidity will be our existing cash and cash equivalents, cash
generated from operations, debt securities (including the Existing Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Secured
Notes), any borrowings under our working capital and bank overdraft facilities, including our Revolving Credit
Facility, factoring facilities and finance leases.

Our financial condition and liquidity have been, and are expected to continue to be, influenced by a variety
of factors, including:

   - our ability to generate cash flows from our operations;

94


-----

   - the level of our outstanding indebtedness, and the interest we are obligated to pay on such
indebtedness, which affect our finance costs;

   - prevailing interest rates, which affect our debt service requirements;

   - our ability to continue to borrow funds from banks;

   - our level of acquisition activity; and

   - our capital expenditure requirements.

Our cash requirements are expected to consist mainly of the following:

   - paying operating costs and working capital;

   - funding capital expenditures;

   - funding potential acquisitions;

   - servicing indebtedness; and

   - paying taxes.

Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operations, future borrowings under our Revolving
Credit Facility and potential future borrowings under debt securities will be adequate to meet our anticipated
general liquidity needs and debt service obligations, we cannot assure you that our business will generate
sufficient cash flows from operations to meet these needs or that future debt or equity financing will be available
to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to fund our liquidity needs, including making payments on the Senior
Secured Notes or other debt when due. If our cash flows from operating activities are lower than expected or our
capital expenditure requirements exceed our projections, we may be required to seek additional financing, which
may not be available on commercially reasonable terms, if at all. Our ability to arrange financing generally and
our cost of capital depends on numerous factors, including general economic conditions, the availability of credit
from banks, other financial institutions, capital markets, restrictions in instruments governing our debt and our
general financial performance. See “Risk factors—Risks related to our indebtedness and the Senior Secured
_Notes—We may not be able to generate sufficient cash to service our indebtedness, including due to factors_
_outside our control, and may be forced to take other actions to satisfy our obligations under our indebtedness,_
_which may not be successful.”_

expenditures include the further expansion of our operations and the maintenance of our existing operations. In

the transport and storage of products in our warehouses, as well as purchases of commercial delivery vans that
we use in our operations. Our capital expenditure on intangible assets mainly relates to the capitalization of new

**_Credit arrangements following this Offering_**

_Notes offered hereby_

Following the Offering, we expect to have €175.0 million in aggregate principal amount of Senior Secured
Notes and €703.0 million of Existing Senior Secured Notes outstanding. We will pay interest on the Senior
Secured Notes in cash at the annual interest rate and on the dates set forth on the cover page of this Offering
Memorandum. Interest on the Senior Secured Notes will accrue from the Issue Date.

The Senior Secured Notes Indenture will contain covenants that, among other things, limit our ability and
the ability of our restricted subsidiaries to: incur additional indebtedness; pay dividends on or make distributions
in respect of capital stock or make certain other restricted payments or investments; enter into agreements that
restrict distributions from restricted subsidiaries; sell or otherwise dispose of assets, including the capital stock of
restricted subsidiaries; enter into transactions with affiliates; create or incur liens; and merge, consolidate or sell
substantially all of our assets. These covenants will be subject to important exceptions and qualifications. See
“Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain covenants.”

_Revolving Credit Facility_

We entered into a Revolving Credit Facility on November 12, 2015, with the guarantors named therein as
original guarantors or borrowers, the financial institutions named therein as original lenders and U.S. Bank
Trustees Limited as security agent. On June 13, 2018, we sought an increase of the Revolving Credit Facility in
the amount of €30.0 million, as a result of which the Revolving Credit Facility provides for borrowings up to an
aggregate of €80.0 million on a committed basis. On July 13, 2018, we further increased the Revolving Credit
Facility to €90.0 million on a committed basis. The interest rate on cash advances under the Revolving Credit
Facility will be the aggregate of the applicable margin and LIBOR/EURIBOR (as defined in the Revolving
Credit Facility Agreement and subject to a floor of zero). The margin may range from 2.50% to 3.50% based on a
consolidated senior secured leverage ratchet and subject to certain conditions. See “Description of certain
_financing arrangements—Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.”_

_Factoring arrangements and working capital and bilateral lending facilities_

Autodistribution and several other of our subsidiaries have entered into various factoring arrangements,
working capital and bilateral lending facilities with an aggregate principal amount of €47.0 million outstanding
as of September 30, 2018, excluding bank overdrafts and certain Italian local lines of credit. These factoring
arrangements and the working capital and bilateral lending facilities will remain in place after the Issue Date. See
“Description of certain financing arrangements.”

**Credit management policy**

We have adopted credit management procedures adjusted to the characteristics of the market and of our
customers in order to reduce the risk of exposure and to attempt to allow prompt and proactive management of
our business. The proactive customer credit risk monitoring activities start by grouping consumers based on their
type, the duration of credit, the existence of previous financial difficulties or notifications and of the possible
existence of legal or ongoing bankruptcy procedures. Financial assets are recorded in the financial statements net
of the write-off based on the risk of breach by the counterparty, which is determined based on the available
information regarding the customer’s solvency.

**Quantitative and qualitative disclosure about financial risk**

In the ordinary course of our business, we are exposed to a variety of financial risks. We monitor and
manage these risks as an integral part of our overall risk management program, which recognizes the
unpredictability of financial markets and seeks to reduce their potential adverse effects on our results of
operations.

**_Exchange rate risk_**

The euro is the functional currency in which our financial statements are presented.

**_Interest rate risk_**

We are exposed to interest rate risks due to our need to finance our operations as well as to utilize our
available liquidity. Fluctuations in market interest rates may have a negative or a positive impact on our financial
results by indirectly influencing the repayment of loans and investments. Following this Offering, our
indebtedness and other debt arrangements will be primarily composed of the Existing Senior Secured Fixed Rate
Notes (which have a fixed interest rate) and the Senior Secured Notes, the Existing Senior Secured Floating Rate
Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility (which borrowings will have an interest rate based on EURIBOR or
LIBOR, reset periodically). We do not currently intend to hedge the interest rate payments on our Existing Senior
Secured Floating Rate Notes and Senior Secured Notes to be issued on the Issue Date. We may, however, decide
to do so in the future.

We evaluate our exposure to changes in interest rates on a regular basis and may decide to manage the
foregoing risks through financial derivatives, according to the directives contained in the “Interest rate risk
management policy” we have adopted. Notwithstanding our potential use of hedging instruments, unexpected
changes in interest rates could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial
condition.

**Off-balance sheet arrangements**

We are not party to any material off-balance sheet arrangements. For a description of certain commitments
and guarantees that we have given to third parties in connection with our financing arrangements and other
ordinary course rental and other obligations, see note 13 to the unaudited interim condensed consolidated
financial statements of the Parent Guarantor as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2018, and note
16 to the audited consolidated financial statements of the Parent Guarantor as of and for the year ended
December 31, 2017, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

**Other financial obligations: pension obligations**

For a description of certain pension plans and obligations, see note 8 to our audited consolidated financial
statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2017, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

**Critical accounting policies**

Our financial statements have been prepared in accordance with IFRS as adopted by the European Union.
The preparation of these financial statements requires us to make various estimates and assumptions that affect
the results we report. Such estimates or assumptions are based on our historical experience and currently
available information, including expectations of future events that we believe are reasonable under the
circumstances. Actual results may differ significantly from such estimates in light of the uncertainty surrounding
the assumptions and conditions upon which the estimates are based. The following are significant accounting
policies determined on the basis of such estimates and assumptions for which changes during a financial period
could involve a significant risk of material change in the carrying amount of assets and liabilities.

**_Impairment of non-financial assets_**

At the end of each reporting period, we assess whether there is any indication that a non- financial asset
might be impaired. The impairment tests are based on the four-year EBITDA plan for each cost generating unit
(“CGU”) as defined by us. For purposes of impairment testing, goodwill is allocated to the CGU or group of
CGUs most likely to benefit from the synergies of the business combination and to the lowest level at which
goodwill is monitored by us. The CGUs correspond to subsidiaries or groups of subsidiaries that are included in
the same operating segment and that generate cash flows largely independent from those generated by other
CGUs.

The assumptions used then undergo a sensitivity test to assess the variability of the result following the
changes of all assumptions. Each year and whenever there is an indication of impairment, we carry out
impairment tests. A valuation of the AD brand is also performed separately, bearing in mind that the impairment
of the brand is reversible if events occur that show that indicators that led to a loss being recorded no longer
exist.

**_Deferred tax assets_**

Deferred tax assets are recorded in respect of tax loss carryforwards when it is likely that we will have
future taxable profits against which said unused tax losses can be charged. The calculation of the amount of
deferred tax assets that can be recognized requires management to estimate how long it will take to use up the
losses carried over and the level of future taxable profits, with regard to tax management strategies.

**_Pensions and other post-employment benefits_**

The cost of defined benefit plans is calculated on the basis of actuarial valuations. These valuations rely on
assumptions regarding discount rates, the projected yield from plan assets, the rate of salary increases and the
mortality rate. Owing to the long-term nature of such plans, there is great uncertainty about these estimates.

**_Inventory impairment_**

Inventory impairment is calculated by applying an impairment rate for each category of unsold products in
accordance with the depletion of items and their last date of sale.

**Overview**

The Western European light vehicle spare parts market comprises three main components: (1) the
manufacturing and supply of spare parts by parts manufacturers (“original equipment suppliers” or “OES”) (such
as Bosch, Faurecia, Knorr-Bremse and Valeo) and the supply of branded spare parts by car manufacturers (“car
manufacturers” or “OEM”) (such as Fiat, Peugeot, Renault and VW) who are in turn supplied with spare parts by
the OES; (2) the distribution of spare parts by OE car dealer networks and IAM distributors; and (3) retail sales
and service to drivers by garages, independent repairers, autocenters, tire specialists and fast fitters, as well as
retail locations (such as spare parts outlets and scrap yards) and online players. We are a distributor in the IAM
of the European light vehicle spare parts market and does not act directly as a repairer in this market.

The graphic below shows the flow of light vehicle spare parts from suppliers, through aftermarket
distributors to retail and service center customers and finally to drivers.

We also operate in the IAM of the truck spare parts market in France. Like the Western European light
vehicle spare parts market, the truck spare parts distribution and repair market in France comprises three main
components: (1) the manufacturing and supply of spare parts by OEM (such as Bosch, Mahle and Wabco) and
the supply of branded spare parts by OEM (such as DAF, Iveco, Krone, Man, Mercedes Benz, Renault Trucks
and Schmitz) who are in turn supplied with spare parts by the OEM; (2) the distribution of spare parts by OE
truck dealer networks, IAM networks and integrated workshops; and (3) maintenance and repair by garages,
certified repairers/agents, and integrated workshops. We act as both a distributor and a repairer in the IAM of the
truck spare parts market in France.

104

The graphic below shows the flow of truck spare parts from suppliers, through the OE truck dealer
networks, IAM networks and integrated workshops to retail and service center customers and finally to owners
and operators of truck fleets.

Light vehicle and truck spare part manufacturing is characterized by a high level of part complexity and
density. Due to the number of vehicle variants in the market and the multiplicity of pieces per vehicle (8,000 per
car on average), spare parts manufacturers collectively produce several million SKUs. OE car and truck dealer
networks primarily source spare parts from specific OEMs and OESs, while IAM distributors mainly employ a
less expensive, multi-brand sourcing approach. Light vehicle and truck spare parts and products can be grouped
as follows:

   - repair and maintenance, such as radiators, alternators, steering and suspension components, brake
systems, spark plugs, oil filters (64% of Group sales in 2017);

   - body parts, such as hoods, bumpers, doors, wings, glass, paints (18% of Group sales in 2017);

   - repairer equipment, such as diagnostic tools (11% of Group sales in 2017); and

   - oil, tires and consumables and accessories, such as antifreeze, coolant, in-car entertainment, navigation
systems (approximately 7% of Group sales in 2017).

The Western European light vehicle aftermarket distributes spare parts to garages, certified repairers,
autocenters, tire specialists, fast fitters, retailers and web dealers.

_Garages generally may repair cars from all brands with IAM spare parts and may be “independent” or_
“affiliated” with a brand. Affiliated garages include AD-branded garages, Bosch Car Service and Top Garage.

_Certified repairers operate under an OEM banner, such as Renault, Peugeot, VW or Fiat._

_Autocenters are generally self-service shops located near supermarkets. Norauto and Feu Vert are examples_
of autocenters.

_Tire specialists principal activity is tire sales and changing. Euromaster and Eurotyre are examples of tire_
specialists.

_Fast fitters are focused on quick service, focused on tires and maintenance. Speedy and Midas are examples_
of fast fitters.

_Retailers include spare parts outlets, supermarkets, scrap yards and gas stations, such as Total, l’Auto E._
Leclerc and Roady.

_Web dealers can be split into three categories: generalists (such as Oscaro and Mr. Auto), online tire_
specialists (Allopneus) and, to a lesser extent, e-commerce generalists.

The truck aftermarket in France also distributes spare parts to garages, certified repairers/agents and
integrated workshops. Integrated workshops are owned by truck fleet operators and generally have a level of

105


-----

technical expertise below that of OEM and IAM networks and, as a result, often outsource repairs other than
routine maintenance to OEM and IAM networks. Veolia and XPO are examples of integrated workshops.

**_Overview of the Western European light vehicle IAM_**

The Western European light vehicle distribution core aftermarket generated total revenue of approximately
€27 billion in 2017. From 2017 to 2022, the overall Western European light vehicle distribution core aftermarket
is forecast to grow at a CAGR of 1.6% to €29.1 billion, due to moderate growth in the number of cars on the road
(the “car parc”) and price increases, which are expected to offset stable job frequency.

The Western European light vehicle IAM is a large and growing channel of the Western European light
vehicle distribution core aftermarket, and tends to be resilient and fragmented, presenting significant
opportunities for consolidation, with high visibility into the future addressable market. From 2017 to 2022, the
overall Western European light vehicle IAM is forecast to grow at a CAGR of 2.0% to €17.6 billion. The graphic
below shows market sizes as of 2017 and growth forecasts for the 2017 to 2022 period for the light vehicle
distribution core aftermarkets and IAMs in each of the countries where we operate, as well as certain adjacent
geographies.

The Western European light vehicle distribution core aftermarket is expected to grow between 1% and 3%
in all geographies shown over the 2017 to 2022 period, with growth in the IAMs forecast to exceed or be on par
with such growth in each country over the same period. This forecast is consistent with the recent trend of
outperformance by the IAMs as compared with their OE car dealer network competitors and the Western
European distribution core aftermarket as a whole.

Between 2014 and 2017, the Western European light vehicle distribution core aftermarket grew at a CAGR
of 1.8%, driven in part by an increase in the size of the car parc, while the Western European light vehicle IAM
gained market share and grew more quickly, at a CAGR of 2.9%, further driven by aging of a growing car parc.
The Western European car parc has generally grown in size since 2011, growing at a CAGR of 1.0% between
2011 and 2016 and a CAGR of 0.8% between 2016 and 2018 (estimated). Additionally, average total mileage
driven has climbed since 2011, growing at a CAGR of 0.6% between 2011 and 2016 and a CAGR of 0.6%
between 2016 and 2018 (estimated), representing an increase from 3.3 billion kilometers of total mileage in 2011
to 3.4 billion kilometers of total mileage in 2018 (estimated). The Western European car parc has also aged, with
the average age of cars increasing from 9.9 years in 2012 to 11.0 years in 2016.

This trend is expected to continue, with forecast growth at a CAGR of 1.6% in the Western European light
vehicle distribution core aftermarket over the 2017 to 2022 period, compared with a CAGR of 2.0% in the
Western European light vehicle IAM. The Western European light vehicle IAM is consequently expected to
continue gaining market share over the same period.

The Western European light vehicle distribution core aftermarket tends to be resilient, stemming from the
fact that even when new car sales fluctuate, the installed car parc requires ongoing repair and maintenance, which
favors the aftermarket generally and the price-competitive IAM particularly.

As an example of this resilience, the graphic below compares the size of the car parc, new light vehicle sales
and the light vehicle distribution core aftermarket in France for the periods shown. Even when new light vehicle
sales in France declined, the French light vehicle distribution core aftermarket showed stable growth.

The Western European light vehicle IAM has a high level of visibility into the future addressable market,
due to the fact that its target market is cars aged over five years. Generally, cars aged under five years are
covered by warranty and maintenance contracts and are predominantly serviced by OE car dealer networks. As a
result, IAM distributors can project today the parc that will be serviceable in five years because parc size, vehicle
types and installed technology are known from the point of production.

**Market drivers and growth potential**

There are four key market drivers in the Western European light vehicle IAM and the truck IAM in France:

   - _Size of the parc / fleet, which refers to the total number of light vehicles or trucks in operation and_
which is driven primarily by new light vehicle or truck sales;

   - _Age of the parc / fleet, which refers to the average age of light vehicles or trucks in operation and which_
is driven by the frequency with which older light vehicles or trucks are replaced with new light vehicles
or trucks;

   - _Prices for spare parts, which is driven primarily by increasing complexity and sophistication of parts_
and systems; and

   - _Job frequency, which refers to the frequency with which repairs and replacement parts are needed,_
which is in turn connected to the number of accidents, the increasing reliability of vehicles and to
average mileage.

For further information on the size and age of the car parc, see “Industry—Overview of the Western
_European light vehicle IAM.”_

In addition, we benefit from a favorable regulatory environment, which is characterized by deregulation of
captive parts pursuant to Commission Regulation (EU) 461/2010 and Commission Regulation (EU) No
330/2010, EU-level initiatives that favor the transition to low- and zero-emission vehicles pursuant to the Paris
agreement, increasingly strict French regulation on technical inspections of vehicles as well as potential future
regulatory developments that may favor autonomous vehicles. Deregulation of captive parts is expected to have a
favorable effect on the IAM distributors, enabling them to address more vehicles aged nine years and under. A
transition to low- or zero emission vehicles, as well as the rollout of autonomous vehicles, could positively
impact IAM distributors by increasing the frequency and number of compulsory testing for vehicles in order to
meet various emissions standards as well as contributing to a more general trend whereby more complex, “new
generation” vehicles drive higher parts prices, as discussed above. Likewise, increasingly strict regulations
relating to inspections could also lead to increased volumes of service and repair.

**_Market drivers and growth potential of the light vehicle spare parts distribution aftermarket in France_**

France is the third largest light vehicle distribution aftermarket in Western Europe. The French light vehicle
distribution core aftermarket is large and mature, with revenue of €5.7 billion in 2017, and is forecast to grow at
a CAGR of 1.1% over the 2017 to 2022 period, reaching €6.0 billion in 2022. This represents similar growth to
the 2014 to 2017 period (1.2% CAGR). Growth of the French light vehicle distribution core aftermarket through
2022 is expected to be supported by car parc growth (from 37.8 million units in 2014 to 38.0 million units in
2017 and forecast to grow at a CAGR of 0.3% from 2017 to 2022, due in part to a rebound of new light vehicle

sales in recent years), car parc aging (with 74% of the car parc currently above four years and the average car age
having increased from 8.9 years in 2014 to 9.2 years in 2017 and forecast to rise to 9.3 years in 2022), increase in
average car mileage (at a CAGR of 0.7% from 2017 to 2022) and spare parts price increases (at a CAGR of 1.3%
from 2017 to 2022) driven by increasing complexity of parts. Price increases are likely to be somewhat offset by
pricing pressure from lower-end distributors.

The light vehicle IAM in France generated revenue of €3.5 billion in 2017 and is growing at a more
dynamic pace (forecast CAGR of 1.6% over the 2017 to 2022 period) than both French light vehicle OE car
dealer networks (forecast CAGR of 0.3% over the 2017 to 2022 period) and the French light vehicle distribution
core aftermarket (forecast CAGR of 1.1% over the 2017 to 2022 period). In 2017, the light vehicle IAM in
France held 62% of market share, which is expected to increase to 63% by 2022, driven by aging of the car parc
positively impacting IAM volumes.

**_Market drivers and growth potential of the light vehicle spare parts distribution aftermarket in Benelux_**

The Netherlands and Belgium are the fifth and sixth largest light vehicle distribution aftermarkets,
respectively, in Western Europe. The Dutch and Belgian light vehicle distribution core aftermarkets generated
total revenue of €1.75 billion and €0.89 billion, respectively, in 2017 and are forecast to grow at a CAGR of
0.7% and 1.0%, respectively, over the 2017 to 2022 period, reaching €1.81 billion and €0.94 billion, respectively,
in 2022. Growth in these markets through 2022 is expected to be supported by slight price increases driven by
increasing complexity of parts, in spite of limited expected car parc growth and slightly declining average
mileage and job frequency.

The light vehicle IAMs in the Netherlands and Belgium generated total revenue of €1.0 billion and
€0.5 billion, respectively, in 2017 and are both growing on par with the Dutch and Belgian light vehicle
distribution core aftermarkets (forecast CAGR of 0.7% and 1.0%, respectively, over the 2017 to 2022 period). In
2017, the light vehicle IAMs in the Netherlands and Belgium comprised 60% and 59% of market share,
respectively, of their distribution core aftermarkets and are expected to remain stable through 2022.

**_Market drivers and growth potential of the light vehicle spare parts distribution aftermarket in Italy_**

Italy is the second largest light vehicle distribution aftermarket in Western Europe. In Italy, the light vehicle
distribution core aftermarket is large and mature, with revenue of €6.6 billion in 2017, and is forecast to grow at
a CAGR of 1.9% over the 2017 to 2022 period, reaching €7.2 billion in 2022. Growth of this market through
2022 is expected to be supported by car parc growth (driven by the recovery of the Italian economy), increasing
car mileage, aging of the car parc and slight price increases driven by increasing complexity of parts. Price
increases are likely to be somewhat offset by declining job frequency due to a reduction in accidents and
improvements to part quality.

The light vehicle IAM in Italy generated total revenue of €4.1 billion in 2017 and is growing at a more
dynamic pace (forecast CAGR of 2.8% over the 2017 to 2022 period) than the Italian light vehicle distribution
core aftermarket (forecast CAGR of 1.9% over the 2017 to 2022 period). Growth in the light vehicle IAM in Italy
over the 2017 to 2022 period is expected to be driven by an aging car parc and the ability of IAMs to offer more
competitive pricing.

110


-----

In 2017, the light vehicle IAM in Italy comprised 62% of market share of the Italian light vehicle
distribution core aftermarket, which is expected to increase to 65% by 2022, primarily driven by competitive
pricing.

**_Market drivers and growth potential of the light vehicle spare parts distribution aftermarket in Spain_**

Spain is the fourth largest light vehicle distribution aftermarket in Western Europe. We are not currently
directly present in Spain. However, Spain represents an area for potential expansion by us in the future and
displays favorable market dynamics similar to the countries in which we are already present. In Spain, the light
vehicle distribution core aftermarket generated total revenue of €4.3 billion in 2017 and is forecast to grow at a
CAGR of 2.6% over the 2017 to 2022 period, reaching €4.9 billion in 2022. Growth of this market through 2022
is expected to be supported by car parc growth (driven by recovery in the Spanish economy) and price increases,
in turn driven by technological improvements and inflation, while job frequency is expected to remain stable.

The light vehicle IAM in Spain generated total revenue of €2.4 billion in 2017 and is growing on par with
the Spanish light vehicle distribution core aftermarket (forecast CAGR of 2.6% over the 2017 to 2022 period). In
2017, the light vehicle IAM in Spain comprised 56% of market share of the Spanish distribution core aftermarket
and is expected to remain stable through 2022.

**_Market drivers and growth potential of the truck spare parts and repair aftermarket in France_**

The truck aftermarket in France generated total revenue of €4.6 billion in 2017, of which €1.4 billion was in
our addressable truck spare parts distribution and repair market. From 2017 to 2022, the truck aftermarket in
France is forecast to grow at a CAGR of 0.8%, due to an aging truck fleet and increasing prices partly offset by
decreasing job frequency. Our addressable truck spare parts distribution and repair market in France is expected
to demonstrate growth at a CAGR of 0.7% in the 2017 to 2022 period, driven by a slightly growing truck fleet
and increasing maintenance costs, due to increasing technical complexity of parts.

**Competitive landscape**

There are two principal types of players in the Western European light vehicle spare parts distribution
aftermarket: OE car dealer networks and IAM distributors. The OE car dealer network aftermarket is composed
of OEM repairers (who are closely connected to the OEMs) and certified repairers. The Western European light
vehicle IAM is composed of a large number of small, independent distributors and a limited number of large
groups, which incorporate a number of distribution and retail brands. The largest of the groups in Western
Europe in 2017 was LKQ/Stahlgruber, followed by GPC/Alliance Automotive Group, WM Trost, us and Inter
Cars.

**_Competitive landscape in the light vehicle spare parts distribution aftermarket in France_**

The light vehicle IAM in France is highly fragmented, with the top two players holding approximately 45%
of market share and approximately 2,000 independent players holding 33% of market share in 2017. In 2017, we
held the largest market share among independent players (29%), followed by Groupauto (16%), Precisium (6%),
Partner’s, Groupe IDLP and Laurent (4% each) and Flauraud (3%). Additionally, some of the large IAM groups
discussed above are also active in France.

**_Competitive landscape in the light vehicle spare parts distribution aftermarket in Benelux_**

The light vehicle IAM Belgium is relatively consolidated, with the top five players holding 51% of market
share. In 2017, LKQ held the largest market share (23%), followed by us (16%) and Geevers (4%), which we
acquired in 2018.

The light vehicle IAM in the Netherlands is consolidated, with the top four players holding 73% of market
share. In 2017, LKQ held the largest market share (35%), followed by Auto Binck Group (26%), Groupauto
(10%) and us (2%).

**_Competitive landscape in the light vehicle spare parts distribution aftermarket in Italy_**

The light vehicle IAM in Italy is extremely fragmented, with the top three players holding only 13% of
market share, with the remainder held by approximately 150 independent distributors and approximately 5,000
“jobbers” (the Italian market includes “jobbers” (ricambisti) who act as an additional layer in its distribution
chain between distributors and garages). In 2017, LKQ held the largest market share (8%), followed by us (3%,
including OVAM, Ricauto and Top Car) and Datacol (2%).

111


-----

**_Competitive landscape in the light vehicle spare parts distribution aftermarket in Spain_**

The light vehicle IAM in Spain is extremely fragmented, with the top five players collectively holding only
15% of market share. In 2017, Lausan held the largest market share (4%), followed by AD Grupo Regueira,
Cecauto, Grupo Davasa and Grupo Vemare (3% each).

**_Competitive landscape in the truck spare parts distribution and repair aftermarket in France_**

There are three types of players in the truck aftermarket in France: OE truck dealer networks, IAM networks
and integrated workshops. Similar to the light vehicle aftermarkets, OE truck dealer networks are connected to an
OEM and are focused on newer vehicles, generally aged under five years and within their warranty period. DAF,
Iveco, Man, Mercedes Benz, Renault Trucks and Volvo are examples of OE truck dealer networks. Truck IAM
networks may operate under a banner (that is, they are affiliated with or owned by wholesalers) or may be pure
independents, and generally focus on trucks aged over five years. AD, TVI and Grupauto are examples of truck
IAM networks.

In France in 2017, we held 18% of market share in the truck IAM in France. The top four players (in terms
of revenue) held 50% of market share in the truck IAM in France in 2017, led by us and G-Truck/Top Truck
(18% each) and followed by TVI (8%) and Todd (5%). We also compete with OE truck dealer networks. In
France in 2017, we operated the largest truck IAM player in terms of revenue and distribution network size, with
200 sites, as compared with its three closest competitors, Alliance Automotive Group, Todd Group and Autolia
Group who had, respectively, 189, 112 and 83 sites. We also operated the second largest distribution network
overall in 2017, following Renault Trucks (300 sites) and followed by Iveco (200 sites) and Mercedes Benz (160
sites).

**BUSINESS**

**Overview**

We are a leading aftermarket light vehicle spare parts distributor and truck spare parts distributor and
repairer in Western Europe, mainly active in France, Benelux and Italy, with over 55 years of experience. Since
the acquisition of Oscaro in November 2018, we have become an “omni-channel” (online and offline) distributor
in the business-to-business (“B2B”) and business-to-consumer (“do it yourself”) (“B2C (DIY)”) segments. We
hold strong regional positions in favorable markets, supported by our unique operational model and value-added
services proposition, our history of organic growth and value-accretive acquisition-led growth as well as our
strong financial profile. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2018, we generated revenue of
€1,379.2 million and an Adjusted EBITDA of €128.2 million. After giving effect to the acquisitions of Verviers
Freins and Oscaro, we had a Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA of €168.5 million for the twelve months ended
September 30, 2018.

We are the market leader in the light vehicle IAM in France, with the largest independent single-branded
distribution network and 29% market share (in terms of revenue) in 2017, and in the truck IAM in France, with
the largest independent distribution network and 18% market share (in terms of revenue) in 2017. We also hold
leading positions around the rest of Western Europe and, in 2017, we were the second largest light vehicle IAM
distributor in both Belgium and Italy and the fourth largest light vehicle IAM distributor in the Netherlands.

We have strengthened our leading position in France with the acquisition of Oscaro, the French leader in
online sales of light vehicle spare parts. Oscaro is one of the first online players to offer new spare parts from
manufacturers and wholesalers, generating the majority of its revenue from the B2C (DIY) segment. Oscaro
offers approximately 1 million SKUs and operates mainly in France and, to a lesser extent, in other markets such
as Spain. We expect the acquisition of Oscaro to help develop our international presence online, as we intend to
roll out Oscaro’s online sales platform to other countries in which we operate.

We operate our business through three operational segments which address the light vehicle independent
aftermarket in France (“Light Vehicle France”), certain light vehicle independent aftermarkets in Benelux and
Italy (“Light Vehicle International”) and the truck independent aftermarket in France (“Trucks”). The pie charts
below show the breakdown of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2017, by segment and by customer.
